2 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERALS DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 1, 1924. Krom: | The Adjutant General of Nebraska To: | His Excellency, Charles W. Bryan, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Subject: Biennial Report of 1923 and 1924. 1. In compliance with the requirements of Section 3305, Chapter 34, Article I, Revised Statutes of Nebraska, 1922, the following bien - nial report for the calendar years of 1923 and 1924 is respectfully sub - mitted. REORGANIZATION OF THF NEBRASKA NATIONAL GUARD Since the last biennial report was submitted, the organization of the 110th Medical Regiment and the 35th Division Train, Q. M. C, has been completed and they are now fully equipped by the Federal govern - ment and are becoming quite well trained. The 35th Division Train is equipped and has been trained as In - fantry and is therefore of the same value to the State, in case of an emergency within its borders, as would be an extra battalion of Infantry. At the present time the 134th Infantry, the 35th Division Train and the 110th Medical Regiment are fully organized, equipped and trained, v hich gives the State a regiment and a battalion of Infantry which, together with the Medical Regiment, makes an ideal organization for a State and will enable it to cope with any disaster or emergency that may require their services. ANNUAL ENCAMPMENTS The annual encampments for the Nebraska National Guard for the last biennium have been held at Ashland, Nebraska, which is fast be - coming an ideal camp for the training of the National Guard and especially for target practice, to which, under the present government requirements, fifty per cent of the time provided for annual training must be devoted. We are now able to have assigned to us for training purposes only the officer instructors and sergeant instructors that are ently detailed to the State, but also an able corps in addition for each period of annual field training and for the annual^^

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 3 instruction. This gives us the greatest amount of instruction in the shortest period of time, and as all transportation, subsistence and pay for these camps and schools are taken care of by the Federal govern - ment, it is also with a minimum expense to the State. Orders, programs and reports of inspectors pertaining to the an - nual field training and schools of instruction for the last biennium will be found in another part of this report. RIFLE RANGE The rifle range at Ashland, Nebraska, has been greatly improved within the last two years, as permanent rifle butts, target houses (of cement construction), a permanent road, a dike and a water system have all been constructed at the expense of the federal government, and this, in connection with the grading, construction of semi-permanent kitch - ens, a swimming pool and a semi-permanent hospital for emergency pur - poses, which have been added at the expense of the State, is fast round - ing this camp site out into an ideal camp. For the coming year we are promised, at the expense of the feder - al government, permanent mess halls, a sewer system, permanent bath houses, and possibly cement floors for the men's tents. The improvement of this rifle range at Ashland permits of our training our own men within the State and thereby giving to the State the benefit of all expenditures made, which would not have been poss - ible had we followed out the first plans laid down for us, of going to some adjoining state where they had improved camp sites already con - structed, and the improvement of this rifle range has also given em - ployment to hundreds of men which otherwise would have been lost to us. UNITED STATES ARMY OFFICERS AND SERGEANT INSTRUCTORS DETAILED TO THE STATE The following is a list of United States Army Officers and Ser - geant Instructors who are assigned by the War Department to the State of Nebraska for instructional purposes: Major T. F. McNeill, Inf. D. O. L., Lincoln, Nebraska Captain J. W. Crissy, Inf. D. O. L., Omaha, Nebraska Captain H. B. Battenberg, Inf. D. O. L., Grand Island, Nebraska Major J. F. Presnell, M. C, D. O. L., Lincoln, Nebraska Captain Jack L. Meyer, Q. M. C, D. O. L., Lincoln Nebraska Tech. Sgt. Lee R. G. Ward, Inf. D. E. M. L., Omaha, Nebraska. Sgt. Merriell Modglin, D. E. M. L., Lincoln, Nebraska Sgt. John Davis, D. E. M. I.., Scottsbluff, Nebraska Sgt. Harry Gilliam, Q. M. C, D. E. M. L., Lincoln, Nebraska Sgt. Paul K. Griffith, M. D , D. E. M. L., Lincoln, Nebraska

4 The above named officer instructors and sergeant instructors are rendering a valuable service and have done much to assist in placing the Nebraska National Guard at its present high standing among the other states of the union. Lieutenant Colonel W. A. McDaniel, Infantry', D- O. L., who has been on duty at this office as Senior Instructor for the last four years, has rendered most valuable assistance to the State, and it was with great regret that we were informed it would be impossible to continue his tour over the allotted four years. ARMORIES The most discouraging proposition with which the units of the Ne - l.raska National Guard have to contend at the present time is the rental of armories. It is almost impossible to rent buildings at reasonable rentals for armories for the National Guard units which give adequate protection to the government property that the State is required to protect, and at the same time have ample space for training purposes, to say nothing of the desirability of having armories that can be made attractive for the enlisted personnel and in which their athletics can be carried on and in which recreation rooms and rest rooms should be provided. Many of the states in the union have made appropriations for the building of armories for National Guard units and it is suggested that the present high rentals be taken into consideration, in connection with the desirability of having armories with the facilities above described, ami that serious consideration be given to the commencement of an armory building program which in time will furnish our National Guard r.; with desirable and attractive buildings and at the same time abol - the necessity of making large appropriations for rentals. Nebraska is one of the few states that have not done anything for their National Guard along this line and the following law, copied from the Revised rutes of Kansas, Sections 48-301 and 48-306, Chapter 48, is submitted your consideration. "48-301. Establishment and use of armories. That the Mili - tary Board of the state is hereby empowered and directed to erect or provide, anywhere within the limits of this state, upon such terms and conditions as shall be decided upon by said Military Board as most advantageous to the state, armories for the use of the National Guard of Kansas, which armories shall be used for drill, meeting and rendezvous purposes by the organization of the National Guard occupying same, and such other public functions which the officers in charge of said armory may deem advisable and proper, and which shall also be opened for meetings and functions of the Grand Army of the Republic, the Spanish-American War Veterans, and their auxiliary organizations. (I.. 1909, ch. 172, sec. 1.)"

5 • "48-306. Amount expended by state for such armory. The amount to be expended for said armory building shall not be leu than $5,000 nor more than $20,000, which shall be exclusive of all gifts or donations made to or for the benefit of any particular ar - mory by the city: Provided, That no armory shall be erected in any city or place unless said city or place donate either real estate or other property of at least one-half the amount expended by the state. (L. 1909, ch. 172, sec. 6.)" RIFLE TEAMS The following named rifle teams have been sent to Camp Perry, Ohio, in the order named, for the years of 1923 and 1924, and consider - ing the limited amount of preliminary practice they had, and that they were competing with the best shots and rifle teams from all over the world, they have made very good records. These teams are taken to Camp Perry annually at the expense of the federal government. Nebraska National Guard Rifle Team. 1923 Captain W. E. McConnaughey, Q. M. C, Lin coin, Nebraska WORLD WAR RECORDS The War Department has furnished this office with a Record of Service for every person who nerved in the Army, Navy or Marine Corps at any time during the period April 6, 1917, to November 11, 1918, and who gave Nebraska as their residence at the time they entered the

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 7 service. The records are in card form and show name, serial number, color or race, residence, dates of service, date and place of birth, or - ganizations served in with grades, dates of overseas service and date and kind of discharge. The approximate number whose records have been credited to the State of Nebraska is 55,634. Nebraska Certificates of Service have been furnished to those whose records are on file in this office, in conformity with House Roll No. 637, 1919-1920, with the exception of approximately 2,500. New certificates have been ordered under the present administration but have not yet been delivered. Numerous inquiries relative to the military records of Nebraska ex-service men have been answered both verbally and by correspondence. Certified copies of Records of Service have been furnished to approxi - mately three hundred ex-service men of this State or to their nearest of kin, for use in obtaining U. S. Compensation, pensions, longevity pay, etc. It has been necessary to cancel approximately 250 records of serv - ice received from the federal government, for the reason that the in - dividuals concerned have claimed a State other than Nebraska as a bona fide residence. The War Department has also asked us to correct 179 records of service. Several states who are paying state compen - sations have been furnished with certified copies of records of service of men who gave their residence as Nebraska, but who have applied for compensation under the laws of other states. CONCLUSION I wish to express my appreciation to the officers and enlisted men of the Nebraska National Guard who, through their cooperation and willingness in recruiting and training their units, have assisted so ably in bringing the Nebraska National Guard to the present high state of efficiency it enjoys. I also desire to express my gratitude to the offi - cers and non-commissioned officers of the Regular Army on duty with this State, for the assistance they have given in the training of the Nebraska National Guard. In conclusion, I wish to express to your Excellency my appreciation for the moral support and uniform courtesy always extended by you to this Department. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

16 NOTE: AH men armed with the rifle fved 200, 300, 500 and 600 yard range* with the sand bag rest. Those men not making an average score of 30 at these ranges were arbitrarily eliminated from further fir - ing and were given additional preliminary instruction. The above re - port is of men who made an average of 30 for these ranges and com - pleted Course A. Pistol Firing No. men firing. 3. No. men qualifying, 2. (c> This organization has been Federally recognized within 6t four months, and has been equipped with clothing and arms for a er period. It was its first experience in camp and the improve - shown in Infantry drill was very marked. An excellent esprit has been developed in the organization. The officers especially received valuable training in command and administrative duties. (d) Details were excessive. Heavy rains eight of the fifteen days of the period left the drill field in such condition that only a small part of it could be used. For the same reason the tactical exercises were eliminated by the Camp Commander. 1(e) It is recommended that more time be devoted in armory uction to the speciality of the organization. It is suggested that a mum of time be devoted to physical drill and close order drill in the armories, but that progressive training be had, using the block system whereby each individual soldier will be required to pass a test before he is allowed to pass from one block to another. The training of the men should be commenced with the School of the Soldier and Military Dis - cipline and Courtesy. When the soldier has mastered this work he can progress to the School of the Squad and so on through the several blocks. The constant changing of the enlisted personnel requires some such fccheme of training. No man should be permitted to drill in the ranks of the company until he has been tested in the fundamentals and is con - sidered efficient by the Company Commander. Sufficient time to be devoted to marksmanship preliminary Rifle — ('ours.' A Organization No, men firing: No. men qualifying \t\. Detachment 8 fagon Co. Nc. 119 14 iagon Co. No. 120 17 I. T. Co. FIELD INSTRUCTION: Inasmuch as the Division Train is organized and equipped as an Infantry Battalion, it is recommended that all instruction be carried on as such with one Instructor and one Sergeant-Instructor assigned to them. NOTE: All men of rifle companies fired 200, 300, 500, and 600 \ards ranges with sand bag rest. Those men not making an average score of 30 at these ranges were arbitrarily eliminated from further fir- ing and were given additional preliminary instruction. The above re- port is of men who made an p.verape completed "Course A." score of 30 for these ranges and Pistol Firing No. of men firing — 27. The qualification course was not com- pleted. Automatic Rifle Firing No. of men firing — 39. The qualification course was not com pleted; all men fired at least 40 rounds. (ci The outstanding accomplishment of the training period is the range work. Practically every man of the 134th Infantry fired at four ranges during the instruction period, and over 150 men fired Course A completely. Had rain not interfered with the carrying out of the sche- dule as prescribed, it is believed that the entire regiment would have fired Course A. Great improvement was made in all disciplinary drills and Guard duty. The regiment profited greatly by the excellent handling of all details at the Pit, details were prompt, telephone service very satis- factory, and coaches and scorers well instructed. Practical work of specialists of Regimental' and Battalion

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 19 Headquarters Companies was very satisfactory, due to instruction re - ceived at Specialists' School. (d) Details were excessive. Heavy rains during eight of the fifteen days of the period left the drill field in such condition that only a small part of it could be used. For the same reason the tactical exercises were eliminated by the Camp Commander. Battalion Commanders were not given sufficient opportun - ity to exercise command of their Battalions. Lack of preparation for Marksmanship. Platoons — only one company had division of platoons and habitually used this formation. Machine Gun Companies were handicapped by shortage of .pare parts. Company Commanders report their inability to obtain -•anie through the U. S. P. & D. O. (e) It is recommended that more time be devoted in Armory Instruction to the specialists of the organization. This applies to the Automatic riflemen, scouts, runners, etc. It is suggested that a mini - mum of time be devoted to physical drill and close order drill in the armories, but that progressive training be had using the block system whereby each individual soldier will be required to pass a test before he is allowed to pass from one block to another. The training of the men should be commenced with the School of the Soldier and Military Discipline and Courtesy. When the soldier has mastered this work, he can progress to the School of the Squad and so on through the several blocks. The constant changing of the enlisted personnel requires some .such scheme of training. No man should be permitted to drill in the ranks of the Company until he has been tested in the fundamentals and is considered efficient by the Company Commander. Not sufficient time is devoted to marksmanship preliminary training in the armories. This work should be begun about January first and a portion of each drill period thereafter until camp should be devoted to it. Machine Gun Companies need much preliminary work, es- pecially in functioning stoppages, etc., before the encampments, and these should be covered in their Armory drills. For the Field Instruction it is recommended that all in- struction be done by Battalions under the Battalion Commanders with on 3 Instructor assigned to each Battalion; that the schedule provide for at least one Battalion maneuver; that the schedule for the encampment

20 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL be divided into three periods, one for target practice, one for close order drill, and one for extended order drill and combat exercises. Further it is recommended that all drills and target prac- tice be completed at noon each day, and that specialists schools including schools for officers be held daily in the afternoon. (f) Strength Strength Officers Warrant Officers Men Animals Beginning of camp 57 1 874 0 1 874 0 Close of camp 58 1 880 0 ( g) In addition to instruction given as covered in detailed schedule of instruction, Specialists Schools were held from 1:00 to 3:00 p. m. as follows: Musketry Cooks and Mess Sergeants Ordnance Buglers Automatic Rifles Hq. Co. specialists, radio, telephone, etc. (h) None. (i) Location — Ashland, Nebraska, first two weeks of August. Selection made on account of excellent range facilities and the semi-permanent installations made for the 1923 encampment. (j) Not given. (Signe.li JOHN W. CRISSY, September 1, 1923, Omaha, Nebraska. Brief description cf camp site, its suitability for training: It contains about 560 acres of land belonging to the Federal Government, located on the Platte River and consisting part - ly of islands and partly of the old bed of the stream. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 27 (h) Terrain exercises None. Total 100c; (5) Brief description of camp site, its suitability for training: Some low swampy ground that serves as breeding place for mosquitoes, gnats and sand flies. It also interferes with ceremonies and drill and exercises. Should be filled in. Prevalence of sand burrs on higher ground interferes with combat exercises. The area of the reservation is too small to be suitable for tactical exercises, and the rifle, machine gun and howitzer ranges are not free from serious danger to civilians living in the vicinity. More land should be acquired to increase the safety factor as well as to provide more terrain for instruction. (6) Equipment and horses. (a) Quantity of heavy equipment taken to camp, tentage, vehicles, field pieces, etc., and quantity obtained in camp. 1. Equipment brought to camp: Tentaee — pyramidal and wall tents necessary for accommodation of men actually attending camp. Cots, field ranges and bed-sacks for all units. Vehicles — 5 Liberty Trucks were brought to camp by units, of which 4 were permanently turned in to the Camp Quarter - master. One was returned to Omaha with Company K. 2. No equipment was obtained in camp. Transpor - tation was supplied when needed from the camp pool. (b) Animals— none taken to camp. 36 horses and IS mules were hired by the state, and pooled to supply mounts and animal transportation for all units when needed. (c) Recommendation as to minimum amount of equipment and animals required for future camps in order to conduct pfficient train - ing. 1. Equipment — same as this year, except that machine gun and howitzer carts should be brought to camp. 2. Riding horses — same as this year. 3. Draft mules — 16" additional to furnish animals for the instruction of Service, Machine Gun and Howitzer Companies. (d) Short of actual needs — 16 draft mules. (7) Recommendations as to future camps: Dates: August 4 to 18, 1925. Place: Same as this year. Facilities: Acquisition of more land west and east of pres - ent reservation. Instructors: Three additional officers are required for ef-

28 fective instruction of this unit, making a total of 8 officers, of whom 5 will be additional to the instructors regularly detailed. This matter is of prime importance, if really good results •re to be obtained from the next field training period. The sergeant-instructors same as this year, except that one sergeant-instructor to give expert instruction in the care of animals, shoeing, etc., should be furnished. (Signed) T. F. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 31 Last Circular Letter 1922 Series was No. 36. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN Circular Letter No. 1 January 9, 1923. Subject: Annual Armory Inspection. To: All Unit Commanders, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Pursuant to Special Orders No. 302, Headquarters, 7th Corps Area, Omaha, Nebr., December 29, 1922, pertaining to annual Armory Inspection which requires that the physical inventory be taken of all Fed - eral property so arranged that it can be counted quickly, forms 637 and all memorandum receipts must be brought up to date so they will be authentic record in ascertaining property on hand. 2. The following suggestions as to arrangement of property in supply rooms so as to facilitate the inventory by the Federal Inspector are published for your guidance. a. Blankets, shelter halves, bed sacks and breeches folded and piled with folded edges out. b. If packs are not rolled all pack carriers should be removed from the haversacks. c. Coats and overcoats to be piled with the collars out. d. All items of one kind to be piled in one place i. e., cotton coats, cotton breeches, canteens, canteen covers, etc. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: SGD. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN Circular Letter No. 2 January 15, 1923. Subject: Unserviceable Cots. To: All Responsible Officers, N. N. G. 1. This office has received repairs for U. S. Army Cots and in order

32 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL to secure authority for the issuance of Government Bills of Lading, it will be necessary to report the number of Cots that actually need re - pairing. 2. This report must be in by February 15, 1923 or this office will consider that Cots on hand are in a serviceable condition. BY ORDER OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL H. C. STEIN, Major Q. M. C, N. N. G STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN Circular Letter No. 3 January 16, 1923. Subject: Care of Small Arms. To: All Officers, Nebraska National Guard 1. Attention of all concerned is invited to the necessity for cleaning and removing metal fouling from Small Arms, Automatic Rifles, and Machine Guns immediately after firing. In this connection, attention is invited to the instructions given on pages 36 to 41, inclusive, of the "Handbook of the Rifle," War Department Document No. 987; pages 66 to 68, inclusive, of "Machine Gun Service Regulations," War Department Document No. 856; and paragraph 81 "Automatic Rifle" War Depart - ment Document No. 845. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 33 To: All Unit Commanders, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Discharge of an enlisted man in time of peace for the purpose o enlistment in the Regular Army, Navy or Marine Corps must be taken up with the Unit Commander by the applicant thru the Recruiting Office of the services concerned, sc the Company Commander may make hi recommendations to the Adjutant General, showing that the man has n property responsibility and that his record is clear, in which case th Adjutant General's Office will authorize his discharge. 2. The applicant's discharge papers will be forwarded thru proper channels to this office and if, for any reason, the man failed to enlist or is not accepted, his discharge papers will be returned to his Unit Com - mander thm the office of the Adjutant General and the order that authorized his discharge will be rescinded. 3. In case the applicant's record is clear, the Unit Command ,-r should wire the Recruiting Officer collect, authorizing his acceptance for enlistment, forwarding copy of telegram with h»s recommendations to this office immediately. BY ORDER OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL H. C. STEIN, Major Q. M. C, N. N. G STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN February 13, 1923 Circular Letter No. 5 Subject: Small Arms Target Practice Form? To: All Unit Commanders, N. N. G. 1. There is enclosed a summary of the u-'-es of blank forms for Small Arms Target Practice which .should be attached to Blue Prints "List, Accomplishment anil Disposition of Records, etc. involved when a man is enlisted" furnished with Nebraska Circular Letter No. 15. 1922. 2. Form 340 AGO: The back of this form is used for Instruction Practice (see Par. 105, Rifle Marksmanship) and the front for Record Practice, Course A, (see Par. 106 R. M.) Form 305 AGO: To be used as a pistol or revolver score card (see M. B. Cir. Let. No. 27. 1922V Form 410 AGO: To be used the same as Form 304 AGO except that it is Course B, (see Par. 109 and 110 R. M.) and in case Course C is fired, this form will be modified by making the necessary corrections, (see Par. 112 R. M.). Courses B and C will not be fired unless a suitable range for Course A is not available (Par. 103 R. M.).

34 S. For Record Practice the score cards will be kept in the personal possession of the Company Commander. Entries for Record Practice will be made in ink or in indelible pencil and no corrections or alterations will be made thereon except by the Company Commander, who will tial each correction or alteration. The scores and qualifications will transcribed to page 11 of the Service Record, (Pars. 140 and 175 R. . The word "Special" on page 11 of Service Record should be struck as there are no Special Courses, now. 4. Forms 307 and 308 AGO: These are consolidation of individual classification in Rifle and Pistol Practice and will be forwarded to the Regimental Commander as soon as practicable after December 31st. This data is obtained from page 11 of the new Service Record or from the forms as listed in Par. 2 above, (see par. 107 R. M. for qualification as to Expert, Sharpshooter or Marksman). 15. Score Books: These have been furnished to all Units in suf - ent quantities for each individual armed with the rifle in which is en all necessary preliminary instructions and in which should be kept the specially prepared pages, a record of all shots fired at the differ - ranges, showing the location of each hit; zero, elevation and windage rifle; wind velocity, wind direction, light conditions and all other in - itiation affecting the score. 6. No man will fire in Range Practice until he has been thoroly instructed in the preparatory exercises (Par. 6, R. M.). The prepara - tory exercises must be taken up in a systematic manner, Training Cir - cular No. 1, Office of the Senior Instructor, N. N. G., dated February 11, 1922 being followed as closely as possible. t7. Gallery Practice: As but two Gallery Rifles per Company are ' allowed, gallery practice should be started as soon as possible and the principles of actual firing taught carefuly, (Par. 6, R. M.). 8. Gallery Ranges: The two most important items in preparing for gallery practice are safety precautions and ample arrangements for cleaning and caring for the rifles (Par. 48, 56 and Plate XX, Page 130, R. M.); if firing must be indoors and at night, special arrangements must be made for firing point, bullet stop and lighting. The following ar - rangements have been found satisfactory for small gallery ranges; (a) Sawdust about a foot deep, covered with canvas at the firing point; (b) Iron or steel plate for back stop, inclined inward at the top to throw the bullets to the ground or floor; (c) Target Cloth or other support on which to fasten the paper targets; (d) Sufficient lights with reflectors above and below the targets and above the firing point. BY DIRECTION OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL: H. C. STEIN, 1 End. Major Q. M. C, N. N. G.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 35 TO BE ATTACHED TO BLUE PRINT "LIST, ACCOMPLISHMENT AND DISPOSITION OF RECORDS, ETC. INVOLVED WHEN * MAN IS ENUSTEr NOTE: There are no Special Courses, they are either Course A, B or C. (See Par. 105 to 112, inclusive, Rifle Marksmanship). Report of Rifle Practice 307 AGO For organization report to Regt. Hq. (Consolidation of the Com - pany). Report of Pirtol Practice. 308 AGO For organization report to Regt. Hq. (Consolidation of the Com - pany). STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN February 22, 1923 Circular Letter No. 6 Subject: Armory Drill Pay Decisions. To: All Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. The following decisions, concerning armory drill pay, are pub - lished for the information and guidance of all concerned: "War Department Office of Chief of Finance, Washington Finance December 28, 1922. Memorandum No. 105. 1. Drill Pay of Medical Officers of the National Guard. A medical Score Card for Rifle 304 AGO Practice. For each man firing, record Course A. Course A. Record of Pistol Firing 305 AGO Score Card for Rifle 410 AGO Practice. Coarse B. Service Record 29 AGO (Ed. Apr. 22, 1919) For each man firing pistol. Course A. For each man firing. Course B. The data from the above forms to he transferred to page 11 of the

36 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL officer of the National Guard below the grade of major attached to a medical detachment is entitled to be paid as an officer belonging to an organization, at the rate of one-thirtieth of the monthly pay of his grade for each drill not exceeding five in any one calendar month. KENZIE W. WALKER, Chief of Finance. NOTE: The above ruling reverses the ruling of the Chief of the Militia Bureau to the effect that "all medical officers" would be paid as officers not belonging to an organization. In this connection, attention is invited to the fact that an officer cannot qualify for pay under both provisions of law, i. e. as "Officers belonging" and as "Officers not be - longing" to an organization, and, under the above ruling, they are class - ed as officers "belonging to an organization" and subject to regulations and decisions (see also Cir. Letter No. 16, M. B. 1923 > pertaining to maintenance of the organization's strength and percentage of that strength in attendance at drill. S25. (Nebr.) 7th Ind R Finance Office, U. S. A., Omaha, Nebr., February 19, 1923. — To The Officer in Charge of National Guard Affairs, Hq. 7th C. A., Omaha, Nebr. 1. Attention is invited to above copy of Finance Memorandum No. 105, dated December 28, 1922, which determines the status of Medical Officers of the National Guard below the grade of major when attached to medical detachments. In the opinion of this office, the provisions of F. M. No. 105, supra, extend to other medical organizations, such as hospital companies, for which the tables of organization provide a com - missioned personnel as belonging thereto. 2. The law, with reference to organization officers provides no drill pay for duty other than drills unless such duty is ordered for the entire organization and is specifically authorized by the Secretary of War, hence medical officers coming under the provisions of F. M. No. 105 are en - titled to armory pay for drills attended subject to regulations as to the percentages of strength required to attend and the maintenance of tr.e organization's strength at or exceeding the mirin-.um required for fedeial recognition. 3. Attention is invited to the following indorsement this date re ceive<l from the Chipf of the Militia Bureau: "W. D., M. B., February 9, 1923.— To the Chief of Finance (2nd Ind.) 1. The recognition strength of the Medical Detachment of a regiment of Infantry is 30 enlisted men; * * • 2. In order for the officers to receive armory drill pay, it

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 37 is necessary that the minimum enlisted strength required for recognition be maintained. For the Chief, Militia Bureau: C. C. HAMMOND, Assistant." E. F. ELY, Finance Officer, U. S. A Office, Instructor, N. N. G. 1445 N. St., Lincoln, Nebr., February 21, 1923. 1. Pursuant to above decisions, officers below the rank of major, belonging to Medical units will be required to qualify as prescribed in Sec. (a) Par. 928 N. G. Regs., in order to be entitled to armory drill pay. 2. Pursuant to the last two sections of Par. 1, Cir. Letter 107, M. B., 1922, Staff Officers cannot qualify for armory drill pay by drilling with a unit unless they have been assigned or attached to said unit by competent authority (Regimental Commander within the regiment and the State Adjutant General for others). November 1, 1922 was de - signated by the Militia Bureau as the date, beginning with which this rule must be enforced. W. A. McDANIEL, Col. Inf. D. O. L. Instructor." Lt. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 13, 1923. Circular Letter No. 7 Subject: Courts-martial Procedure. To: All Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Recent delays in the executing cf courts-martial sentences have been traced to the erronous sending of the sentence to the Regimental Commander for approval. This is unnecessary except where the Regi - mental Commander happens to be the appointing authority (convening authority).

38 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2. The approving- authority is the same as the appointing authority shown in Pars. 72-74 N. G. Regs, and this approval is the one referred to on line 19, Page 6, of Model Pay Roll. 3. Whenever the member of a command fails to appear for trial when so directed by proper authority, the convening authority must give the accused an order in writing together with a copy of the charge or charges upon which his trial is desired, before the President of the Court or the Summary Court Officer can compel the attendance of the accused by the issue of a warrant to a U. S. Marshal or his duly appointed deputy. 4. Where but one commissioned officer is present at a station, he automatically becomes Summary Court Officer, whether he issues an order appointing himself or not. But in signing as Summary Court Officer, he must always place "Only Officer Present" after his rank and organization. 5. After a sentence has been duly approved and all necessary data recorded for entry on Service Record, Pay Roll, etc., the original charge sheet must be forwarded to the office of the State Adjutant General for review and file. 6. Although the State Laws do not provide for a State Civil Officer executing all processes and sentences of a National Guard Court, thereby devolving it upon the Federal authorities, they do provide in Sec. 3956, R. S. of Nebraska, 1913, as follows: "When the fines by Court-Martial or Company Courts of discipline are not paid within ten days after the sentence is approved by the Com - mander in Chief and returned to the immediate Commanding Officer of the party so assessed, a list of such fines, with the names of the delin - quents shall be placed in the hands of a Justice of Peace within the Coun - ties in which the delinquents respectively reside, and said Justice shall thereupon issue processes and render judgment upon proof, against said delinquents separately (the record of the military court to be considered proof), together with the costs of suit, and shall ; ssue execution thereon directed to any Constable of the proper township who shall collect the same." 7. Expenses of confinement of members turned over to U. S. Mar - shal's office will be met by that office as in the case of other Federal prisoners. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 39 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 19, 1923. Circular Letter No. 8 Subject: Report of Unserviceable Clothing. To: All Unit Commanders, N. N. G. 1. The recent State and Federal inspections revealed that there is considerable clothing on hand in the Units that has been worn oat from fair wear and tear in the service. 2. Responsible Officers will immediately fill out the enclosed Cer - tificate in duplicate, forwarding original to this office so that the neces - sary Reports of surveys may be prepared for the action of Surveying Officer. 3. Attention is invited to M. B. Circular Letter No. 77, 1922, that the approximate or actual length of time in use and nature of service must be shown. The items listed must be actually on hand and you are cautioned only to list that which is beyond repair. 4. Unless Company Commanders give this their immediate atten - tion, a number of them will find themselves without sufficient shoes and clothing to equip their command for Camp. This Certificate must be in by April 10, 1923, or this office will consider that the clothing on hand is in a serviceable condition. BY DIRECTION OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL H. C. STEIN, Major Q. M. C, N. N. G. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 20, 1923. Circular Letter No. 9 Subject: Requisitions for Clothing and Equipage To: All Unit Commanders, N. N. G. 1. Requisitions for clothing and equipage should be immediately submitted in the amounts necessary for your unit at its minimum peace strength, plus ten percent for stock in the item of clothing, taking into consideration the following:

40 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL (a) Clothing which is of such sizes that it cannot be used. (b) Clothing and equipage which has been dropped from the property loan records or that which is pending on surveys, statement of charges, etc. (c) Clothing which will be reported in accordance with Nebras - ka Circular Letter No. 8, 1923. 2. Requisitions should be submitted in letter form, being sure to state sizes required, bearing in mind that sizes are now on commercial basis (see pages 9-13 inclusive, S. R. 40, Price of Clothing and Equipage). 3. These requisitions must be in by April 15, 1923 or this office will consider that there is sufficient clothing and equipage on hand to properly equip your men. It is very doubtful if requisitions received after the above mentioned date can be filled in time for the Annual Field Training, 1923. BY ORDER OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL H. C. STEIN, Major Q. M. C, N. N. G. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 7, 1923. Circular Letter No. 10 Subject: Proper care of Small Arms. To: All Responsible Officers, N. N. G 1. Lack of proper care of small arms was noted in the recent in - spections, which will not be tolerated an<> any loss or damage of arms by Irtck of proper attention will result in tho responsible officer being charged with the value thereof. 2. Attention is invited to Par. 797, N. G. R., 1922, to the fact that small arms are required to be locked in the arm racks or arm lockers, which they have been issued. Such arms as are not required to be issued frequently will be cosmolined and packed in the arm chest. In - structions for packing the rifle are found on Page 41, "Hand Book of the Rifle," Doc. 987, '.vhich pamphlet is found in the narrow pocket in the end of each chest. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 41 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 16, 1923 Circular Letter No. 11 Subject: Enlistment of Minors. To: All Officers, N. N. G. 1. Attention is invited to the ape limit restrictions imposed by the new Army Appropriation Bill. Every effort should be made to fill all organizations before this bill goes into effect on July 1, 1923. April, May and June are excellent recruiting months, and by June 30, all or - ganizations in the National Guard should be filled to authorized strength. 2. Effective July 1, 1923, an applicant for enlistment, who is under twenty-one years of p.ge, must have the written consent of one of his parents or guardian before he can enlist. No minor will be enlisted if either parent objects. The age of an applicant on a discharge certifi - cate may be accepted as showing him to be twenty-one years of age or over. The written consent or affidavits of a<»e will be filed with the original enlistment paper along with the service record in the company field desk. 3. The enlistment of boys under eighteen years of age is prohibited. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 9, 1923. Circular Letter No. 12 Subject: Penalty Envelopes. To: All Officers, N. N. G. 1. Complaint has recently been made by the postal authorities as to the abuse of the franking privilege by National Guard Officers, and as many of our officers are now laying themselves liable to a fine of $300.00 for each letter sent that, is not provided for, it is again thought

42 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Esary to invite attention of all Officers of the Nebraska National i to Paragraphs 1011-1014, inclusive, National Guard Regulations, H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 19, 1923. rjlar Letter No. 13 Subject: Clothing and other wearing apparel. To: All Unit Commanders, N. N. G. 1. Owinsr to the fact that many of the men came to camp last year with uniforms that were soiled and that in some instances showed signs of excessive wear and use, and with shoes in such bad condition in many instances, showing plainly that it could not have been caused by fair wear and tear, it is suggested that the Unit Commanders take up with their men the question of having their shoe? repaired and that you per - mit the men to take their clothing home for repair and renovation pre - paratory to camp. Men who have worn their shoes for other than military purposes cannot well object to having them repaired and I think they all have enough interest in their personal appearance so that they would be glad of an opportunity of having their clothing put in good shape for camp. 2. The personal expenditure in each instance would be so slight that I cannot feel that any member of the National Guard would object to bearing it, for at the present time the State funds are so nearly de - pleted that we cannot do it at State expense, and there are no federal funds available for this purpose. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 43 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 26, 1923. Circular Letter No. 14 Subject: Recruitment of Units and responsibility of Officers. To: All Officers, N. N. G. 1. Attention is again invited to the necessity of putting forth extra effort to recruit all units up to full strength during the month of June. In case the new law is made applicable to the National Guard, and it probably will be, after the first of July, it will require the permission of both parents with each of their signatures attached thereto on the en - listment of recruits between the ages of eighteen and twenty-one years. Under the present law, a boy eighteen years of age and older can enlist without the permission of either parent. 2. Units below the required strength will not be permitted to at - tend camp this year, nor will it be permissible to transfer from one unit to another in order to bring this strength up to standard. 3. Field and Staff Officers will be held responsible for strength and condition of units located at same station and they will in the future render all possible assistance to unit commanders in keeping their units up to the required strength and bringing them up to the highest degree of perfection. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 7, 1923. Circular Letter No. 15 Subject: Schedules of Instruction for Field Training, 1923, and year's Armory Training following. To: All Commanders and Instructors, N. N. G. 1. In order that the Regular Army Instructors and National Guard authorities responsible for the preparation and publication of training schedules may obtain the views of unit commanders and in order that

44 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL the latter may have the benefit from the experience of preparing sche - dules, the Corps Area Commander directs that the following plan be followed in preparing the schedules, similar to the methods prescribed in Sec- 9, Par. 85, Compilation of General Orders Circular? an<' Bulletins, W. D., 1881-1915, and later instructions: a. As soon as the general programs for field training (which have been submitted to the Corps Area Commander by the Senior In - structor in the Adjutant General's Office) have been approved, copies of the programs will be sent to those concerned and th<> Regimental and similar commanders will ?ive the necessary instructions to their unit commanders for prompt preparation and submission of a detailed sche - dule showing the instruction recommended for their respective units (based on 8 hours per day) for the 4-day s school of instruction for of - ficers, non-commissioned officers and specialists, and the 15-days camp cf instruction for the entire unit immediately following. (See G. O. 10, A. G. O., Nebr. 1922 for model). tb. The Commanding Officers of the 134th Infantry, 35th Divi- Train (Q. M. C), 110th Medical Regiment, and the State Staff Corps Departments, in consultation with their respective Instructors, will are the complete schedule* to be followed by their respective organ - t>ns during the entire school of instruction and camp of instruction submit them to the Adjutant General not later than July 15, 1923, as much sooner as possible), in order that they may be published. 2. The same procedure will be followed for the schedules of Armory instruction for the year immediately following the camp of instruction. (See G. O. 24, A. G. O. Nebr. 1922, for model). The schedules prepared by the Commanding Officers of the 134th Infantry, 35th Division Train, (Q. M. C), 110th Medical Regiment, and State Staff Corps and Depart - ments, will be submitted to the Adjutant General not later than August 6, 1923. '• BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 19, 1923 Circular Letter No. 16 Subject: Annual Encampment, Nebraska National Guard, 1923 and School of Instruction.

45 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL AH Unit Commanders and all Field and Staff Officers, N. N. G. To 1. The dales of the annual encampment, 1923, having been set, i. e., August 6-20, inclusive, no organization will be excused from attend - ing except when they do not comply with the provisions of M. B. Cir - cular Letter No. 29, 1922, and Par. 932, National Guard Regulations, 1922, as modified by copy of telegraphic communication which will be set out in Circular Letter, Nebraska, No. 20, 1923. 2. All units will be notified later as to the exact hour of departure from home station. 3. Company commanders are authorized to purchase one day's travel ration for enlisted men at 70 cents per ration; rations to be as set out in Regulations, i. e., soft bread, 18 oz., beef, corn, 12 oz., beans, baked, 4 oz., tomatoes, canned, 8 oz., jam, 1.4, coffee, R. & G., 1.12, sugar, 2.4, milk, evaporated, 0.5, per man per day. No other will be paid for out of federal funds, invoices in duplicate to be furnished the Property and Disbursing Officer at camp. Ration returns for five days will be submitted through their respective headquarters, immediately upon arrival at camp. 4. Baggage cars will be placed at the station of the units as de - scribed in Nebraska Circular Letter No. 19, 1923. Personal baggage can be carried up to 150 pounds per individual. Organization equip - ment must be weighed and listed according to its commercial name, giving separate weights, manner of packing, so as to ascertain the classification and rates and to enable recovery in case of loss or damage. The United States Property and Disbursing Officer will furnish the necessary transportation requests to unit or other designated com - manders. 5. Travel Discipline. The senior line officer will assume command of the train and see that travel discipline is maintained, i. e., no men on top of cars or on platform, men not permitted to get off trains at sta - tions without orders, men's personal appearance and conduct must be correct. All officers will familiarize themselves with Article VI, Transportation by Rail of Field Service Regulations. The Command - ing Officer will make a thorough inspection of the train before troops enter at home station, and after they detrain at camp. 6. Travel Uniform. Enlisted men will wear woolen 0. D. shirt*, cotton breeches, service hats with hat cords sewed on, issue leggins and issue shoes. Officers will wear the uniform prescribed for them. 7. Equipment. Enlisted men will carry prescribed individual ami special equipment and the contents of the "Pack" as shown in Chapter 4, Vol. 1, Waldron's "Platoon Training". Extra blankets, clothing, shoes, toilet articles, etc., and the bed sack will be taken by each in - dividual as personal baggage in the barrack bag. The cots are excess

46 baggage. Company Commanders should check each enlisted man to see that he provides himself with extra underwear, socks, towels, tooth brush, paste, hand soap, etc., and that he has extra issue clothing:, i. e., cotton blouse, breeches and O. D. shirt. 8. Additional Equipment. Organisations should carry as excess baggage (freight) organization equipment consisting of axes, water bags, G. I. cans, colors, all mosquito bars in possession of companies, field desk, lanterns, marking outfits, rakes, ranges, typewriters, shovels, tools and all cleaning materials. Sufficient pyramidal tents to provide for six men to a tent, and two additional (one for Orderly and one for Supply tent), all other tentage. All extra shoes should be brought to camp for the purpose of turning in to the U. S. P. A D. 0. field shoes and exchanging unserviceable service shoes. No saddles or harnesses •f any description will be carried, as same will be furnished at camp. 9. Ordnance. All ammunition, all empty cartridges (brass) in packing boxes, Belgian aiming device, all extra rifles and pistols that need repairing, that ordnance with which the individual and company are equipped, fire control instruments will be brought to camp. Am - munition carts and M. G. carts will not be brought to camp as same will be furnished there for demonstration purposes. Ordnance carried in baggage cars will be considered excess baggage. The Commanding Officer of Howitzer Company, 134th Infantry, will bring only such necessary gun carriers, carts, etc., as will enable him to fire on the field. 10. Special Equipment. All signal, medical and engineer property to be carried. 11. You are advised that all equipment referred to in this letter is based upon EQUIPMENT TABLES, NATIONAL GUARD INFAN - TRY. 12. Records. All records and office supplies will be taken, i. e., Property Records, Individual Records, Stationery, Service Record, Morn - ing Reports, all Text Books, all Blank Forms on hand and Score Books. A list in duplicate of all officers and men attending camp will be turned in immediately upon arrival in camp. A list in duplicate of all officers and men absent from camp, with a statement as to the cause of such absence will be turned in immediately upon arrival in camp. Enlisted strength of each unit will be wired to respective headquarters, Ashland, Nebraska, upon entering. 13. Messes. All Company Officers will mess with their organ - Sion and should provide themselves with tables and chairs. Every rt should be made to secure the best possible cooks and Mess Ser - geants, as a good mess is one of the most important things toward con - tentment and good morale of an organization. 14. Officers under orders to attend School of Instruction, August

47 2-5, inclusive, will bring their tentage with them. Arrangements will be made at these headquarters for housing enlisted men attending this School of Instruction. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA. ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 20, 1923. Circular Letter No. 17 Subject: Physical Examination. To: All Officers, N. N. G. 1. In compliance with M. B. Circular Letter No. 6, 1922, all officers who have not had physical examination made within the year will ap - pear before a Board, which will be convened during the annual encamp - ment, August 6-20, inclusive, 1923, for that purpose, and will see that physical examination papers are turned in to the Adjutant, Camp Head - quarters, before the close of the encampment. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 20, 1923. Circular Letter No. 18 Subject: Welfare work. To: All Officers, N. N. G. 1. The following information and suggestions of Captain Harold

48 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL C. Capsey, Chaplain, N. N. G., are published for the information ami guidance of all concerned. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska t "Morale is a very important factor in the efficiency of military inizations at all times and must of necessity be reckoned with for success of an encampment. This year in a new camp, it is very rable that all that is possible be done for the welfare of the men. officers are requested to cooperate with the Chaplains to the fullest ible extent to make their work of real benefit to all ranks. "Chaplain Harold C. Capsey of the 134th Infantry and Chaplain H. H. Harmon of the 110th Medical Regiment will be in camp available for any service in their line of duty and for consultation. Religious services will be conducted, entertainments planned, and the Chaplain's Office may be used by visitors as their headquarters and information "Officer's of organizations are requested to furnish immediate report to the Chaplains of any men in their organizations who are capable entertainers or who might be of special value in any other way. "Attention is called to the necessity of careful instruction in the correct form of address of all mail coming to the camp. This form should be called to the attention of relatives and friends likely to write. Much mail will be undelivered if not properly addressed. Rank and organization MUST be given as: Private Paul Jones, Company "B", 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard Camp Ashland, Nebraska. "All ranks are urged to feel at liberty to call on the Chaplains for any service they can render or for personal consultation." (Signed) Harold C. Capsey, Captain, Chaplain N. N. G.

51 Co. E., Scottsbluff, Nebraska and 2nd Bn. Hq. Co., Gering, Nebraska, 134th Inf. Sec. No. 2, Co. B., 134th Inf. will reserve one half baggage car for Co. A., 134 Inf. Sec No. 3, 2nd Bn. Hq. Co., 134th Inf. will reserve one half baggage car for Co. D., 134th Inf., Wag. Co., No. 119, 35th Divn. Tn., will reserve one half baggage car for Wag. Co., No. 120 and Att. Med. Det, of the 36th Divn. Tn. Sec. No. 4, Howitzer Co., 134th Inf., will reserve one half baggage car for Co. E., 134 Inf. Where organizations are to load equipment on baggage cars fur - nished other organizations, equipment will be piled on trucks or plat - form in such manner as to permit of rapid loading of same, as trains must not be delayed for this purpose. 2. TICKETS: Government Transportation Requests on the Rail - road concerned will be exchanged for tickets at the local ticket office. Requests for berths to be exchanged with the pullman conductor for accomodations actually furnished. 3. RAILROAD EQUIPMENT: Baggage cars to be set the day preceding the movement to permit loading baggage and installation of field ranges, where it is necessary. Tourist cars or coaches to be loaded in a quiet and orderly manner in ample time to permit trains to leave at designated time. 4. BAGGAGE: 150 pounds of personal baggage will be trans - ported free for each passenger. Excess baggage, i. e., Company Prop - erty other than checkable baggage will be handled in baggage cars, but is paid for by the Government on Government Bills of lading, covering such impedimenta forwarded from each station, at freight rates, (See Nebraska Circular Letter No. 16, 1923. These bills of lading will be delivered to the Agent after arrival at Ashland, Nebraska. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 21, 192S. Circular Letter No. 20 Subject: M. B. Circular Letter No. 56, July 12, 1923. To: All Officers, N. N. G. 1. The following telegrnm sent to the Militia Bureau, the answer

52 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL thereto, and the modification of M. B. Circular Letter No. 56, July 12, 1923, as a result thereof, are published for the information and guidance of all concerned. By Order of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska July 17, 1923. "The Chief, Militia Bureau, Washington, D. C. "Reference Circular Letter Number Fifty-six, July twelve, twenty - three period Have gone on theory in this State that company officers could qualify for pay with enlisted strength of fifty period Require - ments of this letter will disqualify eight companies in Infantry Regi - ment period. No more war propaganda makes it almost impossible to secure enlistments in this state period Adherence to requirements in this letter will be demoralizing to Nebraska National Guard period In view extraordinary conditions making enlistments almost impossible to obtain, cannot requirements be changed period Answer collect. "H. J. Paul, Adjutant General." "Adjutant General Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. "Instructions being sent by wire today to all adjutants general which will favorably answer request made by you in your telegram of July seventeenth. "Rickards." "Adjutant General Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. "In accordance with provision of Section Sixty the National Defense Act comma Secretary of War authorizes following general exception in the composition of National Guard units comma for the period April first to September thirtieth twenty-three colon no National Guard unit will be required to have an enrolled enlisted strength greater than fifty semi-colon provided comma that in those units which have been federally recognized for more than six months comma and for which the tables of organization prescribe an enlisted strength of over fifty-eight comma the officers will not be entitled to Federal pay unless at least fifty per - cent of the officers and at least thirty-six enlisted men attend period This waiver of the requirements of both paragraphs one ten and nine thirty-two comma National Guard Regulations comma applies to Field Training and Armory Drill comma but only for the period stated. "Riekards."

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 56 "The third annual reunion and convention of the Thirty-fourth (Sandstorm) Division will be held in Minneapolis September 6 and 7, according to announcement by officers of the Thirty-fourth Division Association. The Sandstorm Division is composed of National Guards - men from Minnesota. South Dakota, Iowa and Nebraska. "The convention is expected to bring together several thousand for - mer service men who wore the Buffalo skull on French soil. Conven - tion headquarters will be maintained at the George S. Lang Post, Amer - ican Legion, in the Hennepin County Court House. I "Plans have been made for all companies to hold their respective nion dinners at the same time and place on the evening of September The program of speakers at this banquet will include Gen. George Rickards, Chief of the Militia Bureau; General Johnson, commander the Division during the war, and Lt. Col. S. B. Philpot, Twenty-fourth S. Infantry. t 'Friday, September 7, has been designated Thirty-fourth Division' at the Minnesota State Fair. Officers of the Division Association Erie D. Luce, president; Minot J. Brown, vice president; R. E. sby, treasurer; and Ralph K. Smith, secretary. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN August 17, 1923. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN August 25, 1923. Circular Letter No. 26 Subject: Training National Guard Units of the State, To: All Commanders and Instructors, N. N. G. 1. Pursuant to the decentralization policy of Corps Area Head - quarters and the Militia Bureau, and in order that the personnel of different organization headquarters may have experience in the issuing of orders and instructions and in the distribution of publications, blank forms, etc., beginning immediately, regimental and corresponding com - manders will hereafter be responsible for the proper and prompt prep - aration and publication of schedules of armory and field training and other required instructions. Copies will be furnished this office. 2. Headquarters lacking facilities for publishing orders or instruc - tions in numbers greater than are practicable to typewrite, can have same mimeographed in the number desired by sending a properly type-

59 written copy to the State Adjutant General, requesting number desired. Typewritten copy to show number, date ,and all other data desired and to be exactly as desired in mimeographed copies). 3. Reference Par. 2, Cir. Let. No. 15, A. G. 0. Nebr., dated June 7, 1923, G. 0. No. 24, A.G. O. Nebr., 1922 (supplemented by G. O. No. 8, 1923, and G. O. No. 5, 1920) will be continued as the guide for armory instruction pending the publication to their respective commands by the commanders named in said paragraph, of the new schedules of armory training. 4. In conformity to Cir. Let. 363. Ol-N. G .(Training N. G.) Hq. 7th Corps Area, dated November 18, 1921, organization commanders should make free use of Instructors and Sgt.-Instructors for assistance in administrative work as well as drill and school intruction, when they are available. 5. Reference Cir. Let. No. 78, M. B. 1922, the Army Correpondence Courses are adopted as the prescribed State school for officers, and al - though this work is not compulsory, it would be of great value to all, and especially to those field, staff and detached officers who cannot attend drill regularly with a unit and qualify for armory drill pay there - by. In this connection attention is invited to the following from the Chief of the Militia Bureau, dated August 18, 1921 : "Training of Officers" "In addition to the work which naturally falls to an officer as a part of his organization, it is expected that all officers will spend the equiva - lent of at least one weekly drill period on individual study. Where possible officers' schools will be organized to work under, the supervision of the Instructor, correspondence methods being resorted to where local conditions make it necessary. In this work as well as in the instruc - tion of units, the fullest possible use will be made of those officers who have attended a special service school. It is considered that they are under a special obligation to give more than the usual amount of time to the instruction and development of the National Guard." 6. Above mentioned Circular Letter from Headquarters 7th Corps Area requires N. C. O. school at least twice per month in Drill Regs., Musketry, Guard Duty, Riot Duty, Hygiene, Military Courtesy and Dis - cipline. Special attention should be given to War Department Train - ing Regulations, which modify the original texts of these and other subjects. The "Cadence System" of giving commands should be taught i-i school as well as at drill, because of its value to inexperienced drill structors. 7. As the Annual Aimory Inspection period starts January 1, 1924,

60 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL immediate steps should be taken to remedy all defects and irregularities found at last inspection. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN September 17, 1923. Circular Letter No. 27 Subject: New Pay Rolls and Armory Drill Pay. To: All Officers and Instructors, N. N. G. 1. Sufficient new Forms 367 and 367a are being sent to unit com - manders for the quarter ending September 30, 1923. A new supply - will hereafter be sent just before the end of each quarter. If more Hanks are needed for any reason, request will be made direct to this office where a surplus supply will be kept. 2. In compliance with Par. 2, Cir. Let. No. 61 .M. B., 1923, the cer - tificate shown in the last three lines will be added to Instructor's cer - tificate on front page. 3. Special attention is invited to the last line of Par. 1, Cir. Let. No. «2. Cir. Let. No. 56, M. B. 1923, and Pars. 110 and 111, N. G. Regs., a? amended by Change No. 3, which requires a maintenance of at least fifty-nine (59) enlisted men instead of fifty (50), after September 30, 1923, for all units for which tables of organization prescribe an enlisted strength of over fifty-eight (58). 4. A careful study of Cir. Lets. Nos. 56, 57 and 58, M. B., 1923, is enjoined. Special attention is invited to the following: a. Although officers belonging to Medical Detachments qualify as "Not belonging to organization", officer belonging to Medical Com - panies can only qualify by drill attendance at which the required per - centage of officers and enlisted men are present. b. 2nd Lieutenants of Hq. Cos. are now classed as Staff Officers. c Only those commanders shown in Pars. 2 and 3, Cir. Let. No. 57, M. B. 1923, are entitled to Administrative pay. 5. The certificate giving the list of property shortage, required of

REPOKT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 61 unit commanders by Cir. Let. No. 33, A. G. O. Nebraska, 1922, will be submitted with these and subsequent pay rolls as heretofore. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN September 24, 1923. Circular Letter No. 28 Subject : Correspondence. To: AH Unit Commanders, N. N. G. 1. Owing to the fact that unit commanders have become very care - less in their official correspondence, it again becomes necessary to call their attention to the fact that all correspondence of an official nature for anyone connected with this office should be addressed "The Adjutant General, Nebraska National Guard, Lincoln, Nebraska". Upon receipt of mail so addressed, the Chief Clerk will sort and see that the mail goes to the respective departments that are supposed to handle same. 2. Much delay is caused in addressing mail otherwise than above enumerated, as a letter addressed to Major H. C. Stein, for instance, is taken to be of a personal nature and if he is out of the city, is laid upon his desk to await his return, when it is found to be purely of a business nature and had it been properly addressed, would have received attention several days sooner. 3. In some instances letters are addressed to the Sergeant In - structors that contain requisition for equipment, office or otherwise, and your attention in this connection is invited to the fact that the Sergeant Instructors' duties are just what their title would imply and they have nothing to do with the filling of requisitions or the furnishing of any kind of supplies. 4. Letters pertaining to administrative work should always be for - warded to this office through military channels, but Drill Programs, should be sent direct so as to reach this office not later than the 5th of the month. Official communication should always reach this office in duplicate. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General,

62 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN November 26, 1923. Circular Letter No. 29 Subject: Armory and Correspondence Schools. To: All Inf. and Q. M. C. Officers, N. N. G. 1. It is the purpose of these schools to supplement Armory Drills in giving to officers and N. C. O.s that additional military knowledge required of them to train and lead their organizations efficiently. 2. Ir. compliance with Paragraph 456, N. G. Regulations, the fol - lowing schools; are prescribed- Armory Schools, Army Correspondence Courses, a. Armory Schools will be estabished as N. C. O. Schools in each unit. They will be conducted by the Commanding Officer of the unit, who will use as his assistants such of his officers and non-commis - sioned officers as he may direct b. Attendance should be required of all officers and N. C. O.s and it is recommended that specially selected privates be encouraged to attend each session. c. Sessions to be held twice each month and each session to be of at least one hour's duration. At least one officer will be present at each session. d. Unless prescribed by the Regimental Commander, unit com - manders will prescribe the subjects for their units. They should nor - mally be those prescribed for subsequent armory drills. A record showing the following will be kept: Date held and duration, Attendance by name, Subjects covered, Grades, if awarded. S. Army Correspondence Courses. Attention is invited to the fol - lowing governing these courses: Lieutenants may apply for Course A of their branch. Captains may apply for Course B of their branch or for Course A

63 Field Officers may apply for Course C of their branch, or for Courses A or B. Since courses and sub-courses are progressive, Captains and Field Officers should scrutinize Course A before applying for Courses B or C. For the many officers who have already enrolled in Course A, the following: will govern: (1) Receipt of an application from a Captain or Field Officer for enrollment in Courses B or C will automatically cancel his present enrollment. (2) Receipt by the Instructor of the next due Lesson Assign - ment Sheet not later than January 1, 1924, will operate to retain the present enrollment. (3) The enrollment of officers who do not take action as stated in (1) or (2) above by January 1, 1924, will be cancelled on that date. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. Circular Utter No. 29 was the last of series of 1923. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 5, 1924. Circular Letter No. 1 Subject: Charts for Company administration. To: AH Unit Commanders and others whom it may concern. 1. Nebraska Circular Letters Nos. 14, 15, and 31 of 1922, and No. 5 of 1923 are modified so as not to conflict with charts "List, Accom - plishment and Disposition of Records, etc.", which are enclosed here - with. All officers and the enlisted personnel whose duties require them to be conversant with the company administration are requested to study carefully and follow closely the instructions contained therein. 2. Special attention is invited to Page 6 of these charts, as the National Guard is entitled to insignia of qualifications earned by its members. All forms for record fire must be authentic, for in addition to the above, in case of call into Federal service, the enlisted men are entitled to extra compensation. 3. In the Reports of Individual Classification in Rifle and Pistol Practice, Forms 307 and 308, A. G. O., under "Summary", the classin-

64 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL cation should be changed to read: men, and Unqualified. Expert Sharpshooters, Marks- 4. Rifle Marksmanship, W. D. Doc. 1021, has been superceded by Training Regulations No. 150-5 and 150-10. Pistol Marksmanship, W. D. Doc. 1050, has not as yet been superseded by any other publication and its provisions will still prevail. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN February 20, 1924. Circular Letter No. 2 Subject: Examination of Officers for Original Appointment or for Promotion. To: All Units and Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Due to the educational and professional requirements now de - manded of officers, to enable them to meet the standards of proficiency, it will hereafter be the policy of examining boards to not waive the examination in any subject prescribed in Par. 261, N. G. R., in which there is doubt as to the candidate's educational fitness, nor in any sub - ject prescribed in Par. 292, in which there is doubt as to his professional fitness. 2. The questions referred to for the professional examination in Par. 249 are found in W. D. Docs. 970, 974 and 1002, and are answered in Waldron's Platoon Training, Grieves' Military Sketching and Map Reading, and the official text books mentioned (as amended by certain Training Regulations and Army Regulation pamphlets). 3. As practical efficiency counts as one-third as much as all other subjects, the confidential letters required by Par. 253 must thoroughly cover all the points in Par. 231 required of the board in making its inquiry. 4. The papers required by Pars. 232 and 233 (when applicable) will be submitted by the candidate when he submits the other exam - ination papers and will be returned to him whether or not he is require-1 to appear before the Board.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 65 5. Instructions on blank forms and in the regulations must be fol - lowed with the utmost care to avoid having papers returned for correc - tion. 6. Under Item 19, Form 108, M. B., all service in the present National Guard must be given as well as service in the World War an. I prior thereto. 7. Colored inks must not he u-eil in preparing official papers, as photostatic copies cannot be made from records executed in colored ink?. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN February 27, 1924. Circular Letter No. 3 Subject: War Department Circular No. 58, July To: All Accountable Officers of Federal Pvcptrty, N. N. G 1. War Department Circular No. 58, July IS, 1923, (Tables of Basic Allowances), is being enclosed only for the accountable officer.- of Fed - eral Property for their information and guidance. 2. Militia Bureau Tables, governing the issue of articles of equip - ment for the different units concerned, have been furnished and they will govern the issue to the National Guard. 3. This circular should be studied carefully, as it contains very valuable information with reference to supply branches to which articles belong; i. e., Quarter-master, Ordnance, Medical, Engineer, Signal, Chemical Warfare, etc.; distribution of articles and basis of issue. It gives the contents of all kinds of chests, kits, field ranges, field desks, instrumentation of bands, allowance of cleaning and preserving mater - ials, number of pins and poles required for all kinds of tentage, etc. 4. Attention invited to Pages 11-14, inclusive, which prescribe the individual equipment for Field Service of Officers, and to the fact that certain articles may be issued while other articles must be procured by the individual. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

66 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 3, 1924 Circular Letter No. 4 Subject: Annual Armory Inspection. To: All Units and Officers of the Nebraska National Guard. 1. The following advance information has been obtained from the officer designated to make the Annual Armory Inspection of the 134th Infantry, beginning March 18, 1924: a. Inspection of last year's report and check of steps taken to remedy defects. b. Inspection of records and paper work of unit, including the effectiveness, simplicity and feasibility of the written mobilization plan of the units and sub-units, and the keeping of local addresses of mem - bers of the unit (see Par. 10, Cir. Let. No. 3, Nebraska, 1922, and Chapter 5, Bellow's Treatise on Riot Duty). c. Inspection of property will include all property (any boxed must be opened), methods of storing, methods of individual care of equipment, etc.; note must be made of all important items of property that are missing. d. The ceremony of inspection will be in full equipment (contents of packs unimportant as they will not be unrolled). Officers to wear Sam Browne belt, pistol, canteen and first aid packet, and to be in same uniform as enlisted men. Coats will not be worn, unless the weather is too cold. e. Drill will be without packs and unit commanders will be allowed to select special men for automatic rifle, signalling, map read - ing, written messages, first aid, and other specialties, instead of the Inspector's designating them at random, but the company as a whole will be tested in military courtesy, nomeclature, use of sling, sight setting, arm signals, extended order drill, etc. tf. Formal guard mounting will not be required. Posting of fs and duties of sentinels and other actual knowledge of guard duty be required. g. In addition to signalling, transmission of written and verbal messages, map reading and other intelligence work required of all units, the Regimental and Battalion Headquarters Companies will be required to set up and demonstrate transmission of information by wire, flag and

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 67 2. Any unit not having sufficient copies of Grieves' Map Reading and Sketching for conducting officers' and non-commissioned officers' schools in those two subjects should request this office and they can be supplied immediately. 3. The inspection will cover the twelve months preceding the date of inspection instead of the calendar year 1923. • 4. The Federal plans for mobilization are contained in A. R. 130-10 and W. D. Confidential Doc. 1116. 5. Semaphore flag signalling has been discontinued for all branches except Coast Artillery. 6. Special attention should be given to getting Correspondence Books, Document Files and all other company records up to date and to having schedules of instruction prepared in accordance with prescribed programs and in detail, and in having them read to the unit and posted on the bulletin board at least one week in advance of the date of execution, in order to have all those designated as instructors to pre - pare their subjects. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 4, 1924 Circular Letter No. 5 Subject: Armory Drills, Drill Programs and Tests. To: All unit and sub-unit commanders. 1. According to some of the programs submitted to this office, some of the sub-unit commanders are requiring their men to remain in the armory two and a half and three hours an evening, and then require the non-commissioned officers to attend schools at other and different times than the drill period. 2. It is the desire of this office that each officer and enlisted man put in bis full hour and a half in honest conscientious work at the drill period; that he attend in uniform and that the drill program be followed as nearly as possible during that period. But it is not our desire that either officers or men be required to work hours, over time, for which

68 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Edraw no pay, and it is not believed to be to the best interests of respective organizations that this either be required or permitted as meral practice. 3. No. 3, Hq. 7th Corps Area, Omaha, Nebraska, Nov. 1, 1923, which reads as follows: "Upon comple - tion of the instruction in any subject, the individuals undergoing such instruction should be tested to determine the degree of their proficiency. Doc. 844 (Prov. Inf. Tr. ual, 1918) should be used. It gives excellent methods as well as t. The results measured by the above mentioned tests will deter - the progress of instruction, rather than the extra amount of time BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J.
