BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 7, 1924. Circular Letter No. 7 Subject: Keeping of Company Fund Accounts. To: All Units and Officers, Nebraska National Guard 1. In order to obtain experience :n the prescribed method of keep - ing Company and Detachment Fund Accounts and yet avoid having these funds improperly diverted in case of muster into the Federal Service, the following plan will be started immediately by all unit.s having Company funds and followed hereafter: a. The Company Council Book (Q. M. C. Form 452) will be used, but have "STATE FUNDS" written on the front in large letters. b. The instructions and model shown will be followed, except that the two pages intended for one month will be used for any desired period to suit the number of entries and the voucher numbers to be continuous between audits of the fund by all officers present with the company (the senior being the president and the junior the recorder), the dates of the period to be shown.

70 2. Unit Commanders will be held responsible that the following inspections of the funds are made and note of such inspection made by the inspector: a. By the Regular Army Officer who makes the Annual Armory Inspection. b. By Battalion Commander, Regimental Commander, or other designated officer at the time of Annual Encampment. (See Par. 90. c By whatever officer is designated, upon transfer of unit to a successor when being relieved from command permanently or tem - porarily. d. By whatever officer is designated, under unusual circum - stances, such as the funds being lost or stolen or improperly disposed of. 3. An additional blank Council Book (Q. M. C. Form 452) may be kept on hand for use in case of muster into Federal Service. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. 1. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 18, 1924. Circular Letter No. 8 Subject: School of Instruction. To: All officers, N. N. G. 1. Owing to the fact that funds available for schools of instruction prior to July 1, 1924, are very limited, and that it is our desire to hold oar school prior to July 1st, the following information is requested by indorsement hereon by return mail: a. Will it be possible for you to attend a school of instruction to be held at Ashland, Nebraska, June 15th to 20th, inclusive? b. In case you are able to attend as above outlined, are you willing to come to Ashland June 15th without pay? This will give June 16th to 19th, inclusive, as actual school time and June 20th to re - tun home on pay. Our allotment of funds will not permit more than the

71 five days pay for officers attending this school and it is not sure yet that we will be able to have all officers in, but we hope so to do. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 24, 1924. Circular Letter No. 9 Subject: Pay Roll Instructions. To: All organization commanders, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Hereafter (beginning with this quarter when the pay rolls are submitted to the Federal Instructor, the retained pay roll of the pre - vious quarter will also be submitted, in addition to the Forms 367b, W. D., for each individual and the carbon copies of Form 107, M. B., for each authorized drill period, required by the instructions on 967b (cover). 2. As soon as the administrative examination of the rolls is com - pleted by the Instructor, the Forms 367b, W. D., Form 107, M. B., and the retained roll for the previous quarter will be returned to the organ - ization commander. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN March 24, 1924. Circular Letter No. 10 Subject: Armory Instruction. To: All units and officers, N. N. G. 1. In carrying out the provisions of Cir. Let. No. 5, Nebraska,

72 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL {4, Cir. Let. No. 29, Nebraska, 1923, and the schedules of instruction pared in accordance with Tr. Memo. No. 3, Hq. 7th C. A., dated Nov. 1923, it is allowable to have shorter sessions than one hour for lory school, provided the full two hours for each month be put in as a minimum. Sessions immediately after or before the drill periods would be preferable. Proper instruction cannot be given to the units if the instructors do not receive special schooling and practice in the subjects they are to teach. 2. In addition to the subjects prescribed for subsequent drills, special attention should be given to field training (particularly that con - tained in recent War. Dept. Training Regulations, Waldron's Platoon Training, Grieves' Military Sketching and Map Reading, and the sub - jects prescribed in Par. 292, N. G. Regulations). 3. Although Field Service Regulations, Manual for N. C. 0.8 and Pvts. and I. D. R. (Prow) 1919, are no longer being issued because the supply is exhausted and they are being revised, they are not obsolete except in those parts that have been officially superceded. 4. National Guard Regulations prescribe that at least a full hour and a half in uniform, exclusive of rests and interruptions, are required to qualify for pay. Changing from civilian clothes to uniform and vice vena will not be counted as part of the hour and a half. The drill per - iod begins when the unit falls in at assembly and ends at recall from drill. Rests and interruptions will be counted as "Time Out" and the minimum of an hour and a half prolonged accordingly. »5. Units having buglers should require them to blow First Call for II, Assembly, Recall, and as many other Calls as practicable, in order keep them in practice. 6. In preparation for the Annual Encampment and the Camp School, outdoor field exercises should be held to the fullest extent as soon as weather permits, and a full course of preliminary drills for tar - get practice given every individual. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 73 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 5, 1924. Circular Letter No. 11 Subject: Appointment of Non-commissioned Officers and Privates 1st Class. To: All Units and Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Recent failure on the part of unit commanders to observe Par. 5, C. L. 1, M. B., 1921 (see Page 10, N. G. Handbook), has resulted in delayed payment and much confusion, caused by the appointment of an excessive number of non-commissioned officers. 2. Hereafter, when unit commanders request their regimental or corresponding commander to make appointments, they will in every case state the enrolled enlisted strength of the unit, the number already in the grade to which the promotion is recommended, and whether it is to fill an original vacancy or vice discharged, promoted, deceas - ed, etc. See Par. 99, S. R. 57 and Page 270, N. G. Hand Book.) Regimental and corresponding commanders will net issue the promotion orders unless the above mentioned data is furnished. 3. Attention is invited to the following decision by the Finance Officer, which is equally applicable to all units according to their respec - tive tables: "Office of Finance Officer, Seventh Corps Area, Omaha, Nebraska, April 3d, 1924— To the Instructor, National Guard of Nebraska, 1445 N Street, Lincoln, Nebraska. * * * * 2. In the opinion of this office, the fact that Tables of Organization prescribe a fixed number of non-commissioned officers for each grade for an Infantry Rifle Company of less than 64 men and a fixed number of non-commissioned officers for an organization of more than 64 men and less than 75 men establishes the two minimums to which reference ■ had in paragraph 5, C. L. No. 1, M. B. 1921, as 65 and 75 respect - ively. 3. With any strength less than 65 the Infantry Rifle Company may have five Sergeants. With a strength of 65 to include 74, it may have seven Sergeants. If the organization obtains the strength of 75 (80'r of the Regular Army minimum peace strength), it may appoint the quota of Sergeants authorized for a similar unit in the Regular Army. If, after having lawfully appointed such quota, the organization •t.rength falls below 75 and is maintained between 65 and 74, no new

74 appointments may be made to fill vacancies in the grade of Sergeant, in excess of the seven authorized for the strength actually maintained. However, a non-commissioned officer discharged for expiration of term of service, may be re-enlisted in the same grade and warrant continued regardless of the fact that the organizations' strength at date of dis - charge and reenlistment is less than the minimum required for the quota actually carried. If the strength of 75 falls below 65, no new appoint - ments may be made to fill vacancies in excess of the authorized quota for an organization strength of less than 65, although reenlistment of non-commissioned officers discharged per expiration of term of service, may be effected in grade, under present law and regulations. The sur - plus non-commissioned officers resulting from decrease in strength of the organization will be absorbed by separations other than by honor - able discharge, and prompt reenlistment. (Signed) W. P. A. T. von Hartung, Acting Finance Officer." BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 8, 1924. Circular Letter No. 13 Subject: Efficiency Reports. To: All officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. The following is published for the information and guidance of all concerned.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 77 "1st Ind. War Dept., Militia Bureau, March 21, 1924. To the Commanding Gen - eral, 7th Corps Area. 1. The attitude of the Militia Bureau in regard to Efficiency Reports of National Guard officers is as follows: (a) The routing of Efficiency Reports is believed to be such as to enable all concerned to gain a correct estimate of the officers reporte'l upon and to take such action as is deemed necessary. (b) The rating of "below average" is considered as an "unfavor - able entry" for the purposes of paragraph R, for the reason that it is believed that such an entry should not lightly be made by the reporting officer, without an accompanying statement as to whether or not the deficiency was brought to the attention of the officer reported upon. (c) The Adjutant General of the State is informed, under the present system of routing of these reports, of the rating made on each officer in the State. This enables the State to take any action deemed necessary at once. What such action should be, is a matter for the state authorities to determine. The Militia Bureau wishes simply to be informed in the matter. If the Adjutant General decides that no action is needed, a statement to that effect should be included in his indorsement. (d) It is not considered advisable to permit Efficiency Reports, which contain expressions of opinion or of fact, to accumulate in the record of any National Guard officer, with no evidence that such derogatory expressions have ever been brought to the attention of the officer reported upon, and which would only serve to cause his dismissal if drafted into Federal service. One of the primary reasons for Kfficiency Reports is to point out the weaknesses in an officer with the hope of correcting them. It is far simpler to correct a few defects in an officer who is partially trained, than to attempt to train a new officer. 2. The Militia Bureau adheres to the position outlined***"**, and in view of the statement contained therein, efficiency reports need not be returned to the Adjutant General of the State, when it is shown that the officer reported on has not been furnished a copy of the unfavorable entries under paragraph R. In this connection, attention is invited to paragraph 1021 (5) (b), National Guard Regulations, 1922, which charges the Corps Area Commander with the responsibility of "making proper requests to the State authorities for the convening of Efficiency Boards under Section 77, National Defense Act." Geo. C. Rickards, Major General, Chief of Bureau. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

79 Nebraska National Guard to appoint a committee for the purpose of ascertaining prices, plans, specifications, etc., for the construction of officers' shacks, in order to enable them to bring their families to camp during the period of annual field training, and in order that same would not interfere with the routine work of said field training, the following officers are appointed on the above named committee: Major H. C. Stein, State Staff Corps and Depts., Major Earl M. Cline, 134th Infantry, Major George W. Covey, 110th Medical Regiment, Major M. L. Poteet, 35th Division Train. 2. Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 22, 1924. Circular Letter No. 16 Subject: Storm Flags. To: All sub-unit commanders, N. N. G. 1. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 1, 1924. Circular Letter No. 17 Subject: Annual Encampment, Nebraska National Guard, and School of Instruction, 1924. To: All units and sub-unit commanders und all Field and Staff Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. The dates of the annual encampment, Nebraska National Guard, 1024, will be July 28th to August 11th, inclusive. 2. The dates of the school of instruction for officers and selected enlisted men will be June 15th to 20th, inclusive, which will permit of arrival on the loth, on which date camp must be prepared, messes arranged for, and everything gotten in order so that the school work proper may commence on the morning of the 16th. Nothing will be permitted to interfere with the program for the school being carried out in fu!i as detailed on the 16th, 17th. 18th and 19th; on June 20th, camp will be broken, the officers and selected enlisted men will be paid and returned to their home stations. 3. A letter was sent from this office to all officers, requesting that tney answer by indorsement thereon by return mail, stating whether or not they would be able to attend the school of instruction. This in - formation was necessary for this office in order that a revised estimate might be submitted to the Militia Bureau, to enable us to pay the officers and enlisted men inn attendance. Notwithstanding the fact that this information was asked to be given by return mail, many of the officers were so tardy in their answers that they were not included in the estimate, it being taken for granted they could not attend. Then from one to six weeks after our revised estimate had been submitted, a number of them informed this office they could attend, with the lesult that we have been unable so far to secure funds that will enable us to

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 81 bring them into the school of insti-uction although we are still endeavoi - ing so to do. In case we are successful, these officers will be notified at a later date and will be permitted to attend. All of this should impress upon all officers the necessity of being prompt in their com - munications, especially when promptness is explicitly set out as a requirement. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 27, 1924. Circular Letter No. 18 Subject: Army Golf Championship. To: All officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. The following letter is hereby reproduced and published for the information of any officers of the Nebraska National Guard who may be interested. "Headquarters Seventh Corps Area Office of the Corps Area Commander Omaha, Nebraska, May 3, 1924. Subject: Army Golf Championship. To: The Adjutant General of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. 1. Bulletin No. 5, War Department, March 28, 1924, authorizes an Annual Army Golf Championship. For the year 1924 it will be held at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, luring the month of September, exact date to be announced later. 2. The Championship is open to all officers of the Army of the United States, including Regular Army, National Guard and Officers Reserve Corps. Two (2) entrants will be selected from each Corps Area. 3. It is hoped that arrangements can be made to hold the Seventh Corps Area tryout at Fort Leavenworth immediately preceding the Championship tournament. Announcement of the tryout will be issued later.

82 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 4. Owing to the lack of funds it will be necessary for contestants for the Corps Area tryout and for the tournament itself to defray their own expenses. Quarters and messing arrangements for the Champion - ship contestants will be made by the Commanding General, Fort Leaven - worth. 6. Request that you inform all National Guard Officers in your State of the above and request those desiring to enter the Corps Area tryout to forward their names, rank, etc., to these headquarters. For the Corps Area Commander: (Signed) A. U. FAULKNER, Acting Officer in Charge, National Guard Affairs." BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 10, 1924. Circular Letter No. 19 Subject: Armory Drill Attendance. To: All Company Commanders, N. N. G. 1. 83 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 30, 1924 Circular Letter No. 20 Subject: Annual Encampment. Nebraska National Guard, 1924. To: All Unit Commanders and all Field and Stan* Officers, N. N. G. 1. The dates of the annual encampment, 1924, having been sat, i. e., July 28 to August 11, 1924, inclusive, no organization will be ex - cused from attending except when they do not comply with the pro - visions of Pars. 110 and 932, Changes No. 3 and 4, National Guard Regulations, 1922. At this point you are cautioned as to the absolute necessity of making yourselves conversant with the above quoted para - graphs and changes, as non-compliance therewith will be expensive for company commanders 2. All units will be notified direct by the United States Property and Disbursing Officer as to the exact hour of departure from home station, rations, handling of baggage, train schedules, transportation requests, bills of lading, making of vouchers, etc. 3. Company commanders are authorized to purchase one day's travel ration for enlisted men at seventy cents per ration, and will fol - low instructions received from the U. S. P. A D. O. pertaining thereto. 4. Travel discipline. The senior line officer will assume command of the train and see that travel discipline is maintained; i. e., no men on top of care or on platform, men not permitted to get off trains at stations without orders, and men's personal appearance and conduct must be correct. All officers will familiarize themselves with Article VI, Transportation by Rail, Field Service Regulations, 1914, and Chap - ter IX, Movements by Rail, Field Service Regulations, 1923. The com - manding officer will make a thorough inspection of the train before troops enter train at home station, and after they detrain at camp. 5. Travel uniform. Enlisted men will wear woolen 0. D. shirts, cotton breeches, service hats with hat cords sewn on, issue leggins ani issue shoes. Officers will wear the uniform prescribed for them. 6. Equipment. Enlisted men will carry prescribed individual and special equipment and the contents of the pack as shown in Chapter IV, Volume 1, Waldron's Platoon Training. Extra blankets, clothing, shoes, toilet articles, etc., and the bed sack, cots and mosquito nets will be taken by each individual as personal baggage in the barrack bag. Company commanders should check each enlisted man to see that he provides himself with extra underwear, socks, towels, tooth brush, paste, hand

84 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL soap, etc., and that he has extra issue clothing; i. e., cotton blouse breeches and 0. D. shirt. 7. Additional equipment. Organizations should carry as excess baggage (freight) organization equipment consisting of axes, water bags, G. I. cans, colors, field desk, lanterns, marking outfits, rakes, ranges, typewriters, shovels, tools, and all cleaning materials; sufficient pyramidal tents to provide for six men to a tent, and two additional (one for orderly and one for supply tent), and all other tentage except latrine screens. No saddles or harnesses of any description will be carried, as same will be furnished at camp. 18. Ordnance. All ammunition, all empty cartridges (brass) in Ling boxes, Belgian aiming device, all extra rifles and pistols that I repairing, that ordnance with which the individual and company equipped, fire control instruments, will be brought to camp. Am - ition carts and machine gun carts will not be brought to camp as e will be furnished there for demonstration purposes. Ordnance ied in baggage cars will be considered excess baggage. The com - ding officer of Howitzer Company, 134th Infantry, will bring only necessary gun carriers, carts, etc., as will enable him to fire on Aeld. t9. Special equipment. All signal, medical and engineer property i be carried; also the glass tubes of calcium hyochlorite and lister 10. You are advised that all equipment referred to in this letter is based upon Equipment Tables, National Guard, with which all con - cerned have been furnished copies. 11. Records. All records and office supplies will be taken; i. e.. Property Records, Individual Records, stationery, Service Records, Morn - ing Reports, all text books, all blank forms on hand, and Score Books. A list in duplicate of all officers and men attending camp will be turned in immediately upon arrival in camp. A list in duplicate of all officers and men absent from camp, with a statement as to cause of such absence, will be turned in immediately upon arrival in camp. Enlisted strength of each unit will be wire*! to respective headquarters, Ashland. Nebraska, upon entraining. tl2. Messes. All company officers will mess with their organiz - i and should provide themselves with tables and chairs. Every t should be made to secure the best possible cocks and mess Set - ts, as a good mess is one of the most important things toward con - nent and good morale of an organization. The Commanding er, 134th Infantry, and the Commanding Officer, 110th Medical ment, will establish officers' messes for the field and staff office'.* eir own organizations and such officers of the State Staff Corps and

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 85 Departments and 35th Division Train, and instructors, as may be assign - ed thereto for mess purposes. Messes are to be operating so as to serve lunch at noon, July 28, 1924. 13. During the rifle practice at the annual encampment, approx - imately seventy-five officers and men will be selected from tho.e mak - ing the best records and will be held for competitive rifle practice in camp at Ashland, Nebraska, for a period of ten days immediately fol - lowing the annual encampment, and from these competitors will be selected the team which will represent the Nebraska National Guard at Camp Perry, Ohio, in September, 1924. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 30, 1924 Circular Letter No. 21 Subject: Physical Examination. To: All officers, Nebraska National Guard 1. In compliance with Compilation Changes No. 1, Par. 206, National Guard Regulations, 1922. all officers who have not had physical examination made within the year will appear before a board, whicn will be convened during the annual encampment, July 28 to August 11, inclusive, 1924, for that purpose, and will see that physical examination papers are turned in to the Adjutant Camp Headquarters, before the close of the encampment. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 19, 1924. Circular Letter No. 22

86 Subject: Movement of motor vehicles, Annual Encampment, 1924. To: All company Commanders, N. N. G. 1. The following movements of motor vehicles for the annual en - campment, Nebraska National Guard, 1924, Ashland, Nebraska, will commence as scheduled. Trucks will load company equipment in baggage cars July 27, 1924, so they may depart for Ashland Rifle (a) Co. A, 134th Inf. Co. B, 134th Inf. Co. H, 134th Inf. Co. K, 134th Inf. M. T. Co. No. 138, 35th Dv. Tn. Range at 5:00 a. m. on July 28, 1924, reporting upon ar - rival of Capt. W. E. McCon - naughey, Q. M. C. N. N. G. (b) Q. M. C— S. S. C. A D Trucks will report to Capt. W. E. McConnaughey, Q. M. C— N. N. G., at State Ar - senal, Lincoln, Nebraska, not later than 7:00 a. m., July 26, 1924. 2. Personnel is to assist of driver and relief driver selected from Privates 1st class or Privates. They will be equipped as outlined in Par. 6, Nebraska Circular Letter No. 20, 1924. These drivers will re - main on this duty throughout camp at the train park. 3. Company commanders are authorized to purchase gasoline for the above movements, furnishing the U. S. P. A D. O. — Nebraska in - voices in duplicate with vouchers, as outlined in File Q. M. No. 12, 1924. 4. Regt. Hq. Co., 134th Inf., and Co. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 87 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 22, 1924 Circular Letter No. 23 Subject: Swimming Pool. To: All Unit Commanders and all Field and Staff Officers, Ne- braska National Guard. 1. This office is pleased to announce that the swimming pool under construction at the National Guard Camp, Ashland, Nebraska, is fast nearing completion and will be ready for use on the opening day of camp. Inasmuch as this pool is constructed very close to the D. L. D. Highway, it will be necessary for all officers and men to bring bathing suits in order to enjoy the privileges of the pool, which is free to all members of the National Guard. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 23, 1924. Circular Letter No. 24 Subject: Welfare work. To: All unit commanders, N N. G. 1. The following suggestions of Chaplain Harold C. Capsey, 134th Infantry, are published for the information and guidance of all con - cerned. "Officers of all organizations are requested to cooperate with the Chaplain in making the work of the Chaplain's office of real benefit to all ranks in camp. "A Chaplain will be available at all times for any service in his line of duty and for consultation. Religious services will be conducted, en - tertainments and motion pictures provided in the evenings, and the Chaplain's office may be used by visitors for camp information. Writ-

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 88 ing paper and envelopes and tables for letter writing will be supplied in the Welfare Building. "Attention is called to the necessity for instruction by all officers to their men as to the correct form of address of all mail coming to the camp. Each man should leave the form of address with all relatives and friends likely to write. Much mail was undelivered last year be - cause not properly addressed. RANK AND ORGANIZATION MUST BE GIVEN, as: Private Paul Jones, Company "B", 134th Infantry National Guard Camp, Ashland, Nebraska. "All company and unit commanders are requested to furnish to the Camp Post Office a copy of the complete roster of all men present at Camp as soon as possible after arrival. "All ranks are urged to feel at liberty to call on the Chaplain for any service he can render or for personal consultation." (Signed) Harold C. Capsey, Chaplain, N. N. G." BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 23, 1924. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN October 29, 1924. Circular Letter No. 28 Subject: Monthly Strength Return. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, N. N. G. 1. Beginning November 1, 1924, all unit and sub-unit commanders will make telegraphic return to this office showing only the total each of officers, warrant officers and enlisted men of the active National Guard of their units or sub-units. 2. This return should be made so as to arrive at this office not later than the third day of each month and is in addition to the regular detailed return now prescribed. 3. This action has been made necessary by the necessity of the Militia Bureau to keep an accurate and up-to-date check on the develop - ment of the National Guard, in order to be able to keep within the budget allowance for the present fiscal year. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska

Circular Letter No. 31 Subject: National Rifle Association of America. To: All Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. The following letter from Brigadier General F. H. Phillips, Jr., Secretary, National Rifle Association of America, is herewith published for the information of all officers. The National Rifle Association of America has been of great assistance in the promotion of rifle practice and in other ways to the National Guard, and it is recommended that

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 93 all officers who feel themselves financially able, render such assistance to the Association as is asked for in this letter. "The National Uifle Association of America Washington, D. C. October 22, 1924. "Brig. Gen. Herbert J. Paul, The Adjutant General of Nebraska, National Rifle Association Director, Lincoln, Nebraska. My Dear General: It is a peculiar fact that relatively few National Guard officers actively support the work of the National Rifle Association. Prac - tically all of them are interested in seeing the work carried through but they do not stop to think of the immediate bearing that the activ - ities of the Association have on the shooting of the Guard. We be - lieve that if it was called to the attention of the officers of your state that the National Rifle Association was responsible for the original law authorizing the holding of the National Matches and has been instru - mental each year since the inception of the Matches in obtaining the passage of the necessary legislation to assure the continuation of the matches, if the officers were reminded of the fact that the present high state of development of the Springfield rifle and ammunition, particular - ly Match ammunition, is due to the continual efforts of the NRA, if it was mentioned that the adoption of the new .22 calibre Springfield was largely a result of the Association's activities, if the work of the NRA in introducing rifle shooting to the high schools and colleges of th country were called to their attention, and if the considerable strides in the interests of the Police Departments, in the matter of properly taking care of and handling their guns, were impressed on the Guard Officers, we believe that they would agree that the Association deserved their support both morally and actively. The active support of the Guard Officers of your state would have a double result. In the first place, it would give the National Rifle Association a much greater weight in its arguments before Congress and would give it considerable greater prestige locally. In the second place, the Guard would be assured of the considerable added incentive to a greater interest in small arms practice, which would result from the circulars and programs we are continually sending individual mem - bers of the Association. Your cooperation in enlisting the support of your officers will, needless to say, be greatly appreciated. If you can issue a memo - randum relative to the subject we will be very glad to furnish appli - cation blanks or will accept the application of your officers by letter if they will indicate their name, rank, organization, age and mailing

94 address. It is customary to require individual members of the Asso - ciation to be vouched for by some one who is already a member, or some police official or regular army or guard officer. This provision of coarse will not apply to the officers of your organization who desire to join us in the work we are trying to do. Annual memberships cost but two dollars per year and the applications received from this time forth will be credited for the balance of 1924 and all of 1925. As you know, the situation relative to the National Matches and the general promotion of rifle practice in this country is rather acute. There is nothing which will be of greater value to us in our efforts to Rave the situation than to be able to point to a one hundred per cent enrollment of the National Guard Officers of the various states. Your reply will be awaited with more than usual interest. Very truly yours, (Signed) F. H. Phillips, Jr., Secretary. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN November 26, 1924. Circular Letter No. 32 Subject: Additional Appropriation, Nebraska National Guard To: All Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Chapter 34, Article I, Section 3343, Compiled Statutes of Ne - braska for 1922, provides among other things that: "For all enlisted men $1.00 per diem additional pay may be allowed in the discretion of the commander-in-chief." This is for the National Guard when in actual service of the State in camps of instruction or in time of war, insurrection, invasion, or reasonable apprehension thereof. 2. In submitting the budget for the Nebraska National Guard for the coming biennium, an additional sum of $45,000.00 is requested so aa to enable us to pay our enlisted men $1.00 per diem while attending camps, schools of instruction, etc., as provided above. S. The coming session of the legislature will undoubtly desire to

95 make a record for economy and it will therefore be very hard to get through any increased appropriation. Owing to the fact that the cry in this section of the country has been for economy and reduced taxes, I have waited until the present time to ask for this sum, to which 1 feel the enlisted men are entitled, but now that I have asked for it, I request every officer to take the matter up with all senators and repre - sentatives upon whom he can bring any influence, in an endeavor to push the appropriation through. This should also be taken up with the enlisted men as a large percent of them have influence with their repre - sentatives and can do much in aiding us to go over the top. 4. It should be borne in mind that this is the year when it will be hard to get this appropriation through and if we are successful this time, we will have the precedent established and I anticipate no trouble then in continuing the appropriation so our enlisted men will be guar - anteed this sum in the future. However, if we fail this time, it will make it doubly hard in the future to establish the precedent. Many of the other states do this for their enlisted men and Nebraska cannot afford to show a lack of appreciation for what her enlisted men in the National Guard are doing. We hope to have correct data as to just what states are paying their enlisted men extra pay and the amount paid by each in the near future and will furnish you this information as soon as obtained. 5. If we are successful in getting this appropriation over, it is going to be a wonderful thing for the Nebraska National Guard, so strike now while the iron is hot and then keep striking until you have secured the promise of your senators and representatives to support this measure. Don't take "No" for an answer. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN November 28, 1924. Circular Letter No. 33 Subject: Adjusted Compensation Act (The Bonus). To: All Officers, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Your attention is invited to copy of letter from The Chief, Militia Bureau, and letter from the Adjutant General of the Army, with reference to the above named subject, which will be self-explanatory.

96 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2. Each company commander has been furnished copies of instruc - tions, application blanks and penalty envelopes for the purpose of assisting ex-service men in obtaining their bonus, but in case more are desired, they will be furnished upon application to this office. 3. As set out in General Rickards' letter, this is an opportunity for the National Guard to render valuable service to the government and to make many friends for itself in getting behind this and helpin c former veterans to help themselves. Let's put our shoulders to the wheel and push this through, each doing all he can in the community in which he resides. BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General Nebraska (COPY) War Department Militia Bureau Washington In reply refer to 240 (Bonus) Gen-1 November 21, 1924. Subject: Administration of Adjusted Compensation Act (the Bonus). To: The Adjutant General of Nebraska. 1. Your attention is invited to enclosed copy of letter from Major General Robert C. Davis, Adjutant General of the Army, to the Chief of the Militia Bureau, dated November 7, 1924, with regard to speeding up applications of those World War veterans who may be entitled to adjusted compensation and who desire to take advantage of the benefits conferred by the Adjusted Compensation Act (the Bonus). 2. The letter speaks for itself, but your attention is particularly invited to the last two paragraphs and to the last sentence of the first paragraph of said letter. 3. It is earnestly hoped that State Adjutants General may find it possible to take such action as will bring this matter to the attention of present and former members of the National Guard. It is felt that great impetus could be given the matter if National Guard organ - izations would interest themselves in aiding and advising the veterans in their localities as to obtaining, making out and forwarding their blanks to the War Department. Certainly the National Guard could render a valuable service to the Government and make many friends

97 for itself, should it get behind this thing and help former veterans to help themselves. It should be urged upon those who do not intend to apply for compensation, either now or eventually, to communicate that fact to The Adjutant General of the Army, in order that the War De - partment may more accurately estimate the task remaining before it and thereby reduce the cost of administration of the benefits conferred. 4. Should you desire blanks sent to any organization or individual of the National Guard, they will be forwarded upon advice from you. (Signed) Geo. C. Rickards, Major General, Chief, Militia Bureau. (COPY) War Department The Adjutant General's Office Washington November 7, 1924. Major General George C. Rickards, Chief of Militia Bureau, Washington, D. C. My dear General Rickards: The War Department is making an appeal to veterans of the World War, through the press and other agencies available to it, to submit their applications at once if they intend to apply eventually for adjust - ed compensation. It is also requesting those who do not desire to avail themselves of the benefits of the Adjusted Compensation Act to* com - municate that fact to the Department. ****** It is thought that there are numerous members and former mem - bers of the National Guard who intend to apply but who have not done so as yet. It would help if they could be urged to submit their ap - plications at once. The various units of the National Guard could also be of great assistance in aiding and advising veterans in their localities in obtaining, making out, and forwarding their blanks to the Department. The inclosures, it is thought, will furnish you with sufficient data on which to base any action you may take. Should you desire blanks sent to any organization or individual of the National Guard, they will be forwarded upon advice from you. Your cooperation and assistance will be greatly appreciated in this matter. Sincerely yours, ROBERT C. DAVIS, Major General, The Adjutant General.

Adjutant General, Nebr. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN July 9, 1923. {General Orders, ) No. 7 S 1. Pursuant to authority contained in letter MB-354.1 — Nebraska, dated June 28, 1923, and letter MB-121.4-Nebra.ska, dated July 2, 1923, the 134th Regiment of Infantry, 110th Medical Regiment, 35th Division Train and State Staff Corps and Departments, will go into Camp of In - struction on Government Rifle Range, Ashland, Nebraska, August 6 to 20 inclusive, 1923, under command of Colonel Herbert J. Paul, Adjutant General's Department, State Staff Corps and Departments, and upon completion of this tour of duty, the above named organizations will be returned to their home stations. 2. Attention is invited to Par. 932, N. G. R., 1922, and changes No. 3, N. G. R., March 22, 1923, and changes No. 4, N. G. R., June 13, 1923. A strict compliance with these citations will be adhered to. 3. Details as to transportation, train schedules, supplies, etc., will be handled by letter from this office. 4. The travel directed is necessary in the military service of the State. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN Asst. Adjutant General, Nebr.

104 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN July 14, 1923. I General Orders, ) 1 No. 8 J The following program prepared in compliance with Par. 459 Nation - al Guard Regulations, by the Assistant Instructor for Infantry and the Instructor 35th Division Train, Q. M. C, is prescribed for the Camp of Instruction at Ashland, Nebraska, for the four days School of Instruction for Commissioned Officers and selected non commissioned officers from August 2 to 5th inclusive and for all units from August 6 to 20th inclus - ive. (Subject to change by the Camp Commander, when necessary be - cause of weather conditions or other circumstances). BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General. GENERAL PRINCIPLES t Because of the paramount importance in the use of weapons as nents of -destruction, estimating distance, observation drills and exercises connected with musketry, the schedule is arranged to require all troops armed with the rifle to devote fifty per cent of the required time to firing or other instruction on the target range. Par. 477 National Guard Regulations will be complied with. 2. Staff officers and enlisted men and specialists whose duties and instructions are not prescribed in this schedule, are to perform, as far as practicable, all functions appropriate to their respective grades and offices as would devolve upon them in a Camp for actual field service. (See G. O. 21, A. G. O., Nebr., 1921; Training Cir. 1, Inf., M. B., 1921, and special W. D. Documents, for subjects in which specialists should be instructed). tS. The Guard and other daily camp details are to be furnished by s not firing. The pit and other range details are to be furnished i the units firing. 4. That training to be emphasized in Camp, which is most difficult to carry out in armory drill. 5 All theories to be taught by practical demonstration and the students to actually put into effect what they have been taught.

105 6. Evening Conferences and attendance thereat will be designated by the Camp Commander. Some subjects suitable for lectures at these conferences are the following, in addition to a critique of that day's work and plans for the following day: Manual for Courts Martial. Infantry Training (including attached staff units). The soldier's "Pack" and equipment. Security and Information. The Machine Gun and its characteristics. Marksmanship and musketry. Physical drill and Bayonet drill. Discipline, courtesy, customs, common sense and discretion. Communication (Signalling and Field Message Blank). Topography and Sketching. Riot duty, guard duty and semi-military duty. Tornado, flood, fire or other emergency call. Field Engineering. Night Operations. "Cadence System" and "Block System" of drill. CAMP ROUTINE Forenoon 5:45 First Call. 5:55 Reveille. '3:00 Assembly for Reveille and 6:15 Mess Call. Roll Call. 6:45 Sick Call and Fatigue Call 7:10 First Call for Drill. Company Police. 7:15 Assembly. 11:45 Recall. 11:55 First Sergeant's Call. 12:00 Mess Call. Afternoon 12:50 First Call for drill. 1 :00 Assembly. 4:30 Recall. Sick Call. 4:40 First Call for Guard Mount. 4:45 Assembly. 5:05 First Call. Parade and Retreat. 5:15 Assembly. 6:00 Mess. 9:00 Tattoo. 10:45 Call to Quarters. 11:00 Taps. Note: Sundays and holidays, Reveille and Breakfast calls will be blown one hour later.

Adjutant General, Nebr. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN August 6, 1923. I General Orders, [ ( No. 12 ) The Commander-in-Chief announces with profound sorrow, the death of Major Paul R. Hclligan, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard. Major Haliigan enlisted in Company E, 5th Nebraska Infantry June 25, 1916; discharged to accept commission June 25, 1916. Com - missioned Captain, Company E, 5th Nebraska Infantry, July 13, lyiti, to rank from June 25, 1916. Mexican Border Service under call of Presi dent, June 18, 1916. Mustered out of Federal service February 21, 1917 Called into service of United States, July 15, 1917. Drafted into Feder al service August 5, 1917. Fifth Infantry, Nebraska National Guard (134th Inf.) to November 13, 1918; 60th Infantry to February 10, 1919; 47th Infantry to December 11, 1918; Infantry unattached to discharge. Served overseas October 13, 1918, to January 2, 1920. Honorably dis - charged January 12, 1920. Commissioned Major, 3rd battalion, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, May 13, 1921. Served to leath, August 3, 1923. Major Halligan's service has been of most unusual value to the Na - tional Guard of this State, having been an active supporter and diligent

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 132 worker in same until entering the World War with his command, when his company as a unit of the 5th Nebraska National Guard was con - verted with the regiment into the 134th United States Infantry, with which he served until it was disbanded in France, when he was assigned to command a company in the 60th Infantry and served in the occupation of Germany. Upon his return to the United States he immediately associated himself with the Adjutant General's Office and rendered valu - able assistance in the reorganization of the National Guard of ihif State, into which he sntered and served until his death with the rank of Major. Major Mulligan was commonly known among his comrades and in - timate friends as "Hap", being a shortening of the title "Happy", which was conferred upon him in his college days on account of his sunny and happy disposition, which he retained to the last and which assisted much in inspiring his associates to greater and better efforts and for which he was universally loved by officers and men alike. Major Halligan will long be remembered as one of the able and efficient officers of the Nebraska National Guard, the sympathy of which is extended to his entire family in this, their hour of sorrow. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General, Nebr. 134 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN March 20, 1924. 1 General Orders, ( No. 3 I 1. The Commander-in-Chief announces with profound sorrow the death of Major Lawrence E. Jones, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard. 2. Major Lawrence E. Jones enlisted in Company "C" 1st Nebraska Infantry, July 29, 1900. Appointed Corporal, December 1, 1901. Ap - pointed 2nd Lieutenant, September 8, 1902. Honorably discharged July 1, 1906, non- residence. Re-enlisted in Company C, 5th Nebraska In - fantry, January 4, 1915. Appointed Corporal, March 1, 1915. Honor - ably discharged to accept commission, April 20, 1915. Appointed 2nd Lieutenant, Company C, 5th Nebraska Infantry, April 20, 1915. Ap - pointed 1st Lieutenant, Company C, 5th Nebraska Infantry, November 10, 1915. Appointed Captain, Company C, 5th Nebraska Infantry, May 9, 1916. Mexican Border Service under call of President, June 18, 1916. Mustered out of Federal service, February 21, 1917. April 9, 1917, re - lieved as Commanding Officer, Company C, 5th Nebraska Infantry, and transferred to unassigned list. Resigned April 23, 1917. June 1, 1917, to August 1, 1917, Officers' Training Camp, Fort Snelling, Minn. Cap - tain 366th Infantry, August 15, 1917. Served overseas June 15, 1918, to February 28, 1919. Honorably discharged April 16, 1919, services no longer required. Appointed Captain, Company G, 134th Infantry, December 11. 1920. Appointed Major, 2nd Bn., 134th Infantry, Febru - ary 19, 1923. Served to date of death, March 18, 1924. 3. Major Jones' service has been of inestimable value to the Na- | tional Guard of this State, having been an active supporter and diligent worker in same until after Mexican Border Service in 1916, when upon his return to his home station, he resigned as Captain of Company "C", 5th Nebraska Infantry, on account of change of residence. When the country needed officers and men for the World War, he immediately tendered his services, went through a training camp and came out with the rank of Captain, under which commission he served with the 366th Infantry until April 16, 1919, when he was honorably discharged. Upon his return to Nebraska and taking up his residence at Hastings, he im - mediately interested himself in the organization of Company "G", 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard and upon its organization was ap - pointed Captain and remained at its head until promoted to the rank of Major, whieh commission he enjoyed until his death, March 18, 1924.

135 4. Major Jones will long be remembered as one of the able and ef - ficient officers of the Nebraska National Guard, the sympathy of which is extended to his family in this, their hour of sorrow. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General, Nebr. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN May 10, 1924. { General Orders, ) \ No. 4 J 1. In recognition of Memorial Day, Friday, May 30, 1924, conse - crated to the brave soldiers who sacrificed their lives for the American Republic, the National flag will, in accordance with paragraph 449 of the Regulations for the United States Army, be displayed on all Armories and all stations of the Nebraska National Guard at half staff from sun - rise until noon on that day. To assist in the observance of the day by Veteran organizations, Commanding Officers of organizations not in the Federal service will place their respective commands at the disposal of local representatives of the Grand Army of the Republic on that day. 2. Owing to the fact that credit for drill will be given for these exercises, no other report will be necessary. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General, Nebr.

No. 130: Major, 2 1st Lts., 1st Sgt., Cook, Bugler, Pvt. 1st class. <5> Vet. Co. No. 110: Captain, 1st Sgt., Cook, Bugler, Pvt. 1st class. 2. Owing to the fact that this four day school will be held exclus - ive of travel time to and from encampment, all officers and enlisted men are directed to report at the Ashland Rifle Range, Ashland, Nebraska, at the earliest possible hour on June 15, 1924, in order that camp, messes, etc., may be established and in working order, so as not to interfere in any way with the regular school routine which will commence the first thing on the morning of June 16, 1924; likewise, no attempt or work toward breaking camp will be permitted until June 20, 1924. After re - porting at camp, no officers or enlisted men will be permitted to leave same without permission from the Commanding Officer. 3. The Commanding Officer, 134th Infantry, will establish an Offi - cers' Mess for his Field and Staff Officers and such officers assigned as Instructors and from State Staff Corps and Departments as may be assigned thereto for mess. 4. The Commanding Officer, 110th Medical Regiment, will estab - lish an Officers' Mess for his Field and Staff Officers and such officers from the 35th Division Train, Instructors and State Staff Corps and Departments, as may be assigned thereto for mess. 5. Lieutenant Michael A. Blodgett, Q. M. C, will establish mess for all enlisted men selected for this camp of instruction. 6. The above messes will be established so as to serve dinner at twelve o'clock noon on date of arrival in camp; i. e., June 15, 1924, and will continue throughout the period of camp of instruction; i. e., June 15 to 20, 1924, inclusive. 7. Dishes for officers' mess will be furnished by the Adjutant Gen-

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 139 ft. Captain J. If. TurbyfiU, 134th Infantry, is hereby placed in command of the Provisional Company consisting of selected non com - missioned officers and privates for the period of the camp of instruction. He will select ont lieutenant, 35th Division Train, and one lieutenant, 110th Medical Regiment, other than the lieutenant placed in charge of the enlisted men's mess (see Par. 5 hereof), as assistants, reporting same to the Camp Commander upon arrival in camp, when they will b* detailed by camp order. 9. All officers upon arrival in caivp will immediately report to the Camp Commander in person and will furnish the Adjutant data giving time of arrival, strength of detachment brought, etc. 10. If at the last minute it is ascertained that officers or enlisted men of the higher grade are unable to attend the camp of instruction, organization commanders are hereby authorized to fill the vacancies thus created from the same grade or junior grade, but in no instance >wll a vacancy be filled by designating one of a higher grade than aet oat in these orders pertaining to each organization. 11. All officers will be required to bring their own tentage or ar - range for it, and will bring their own bedding and tent equipment. Each officer and enlisted man will bring his own cot and mosquito bar. 12. The Commanding Officer, Company "K", 134th Infantry, will transport ail of his tentage and field range to the Ashland Rifle Rang*, Ashland, Nebraska, by truck, leaving Omaha not later than eight o'clock A. M., June 15, 1924. Field range and tentage will be augmented from these headquarters by rolling kitchen and necessary tentage to house six men to a tent. 13. Travel Uniform. Enlisted men will wear woolen O. D. shirts, cotton breeches, service hats with hat cords sewn on, issue leggins and issue shoes. Officers will wear the uniform prescribed for them. 14. Equipment. Enlisted men will carry prescribed individual and special equipment and the contents of tne "Pack" as shown in Chapter 4, Volume I, Waldron's "Platoon Training." Extra blankets, clothing, shoes, toilet articles, etc., and the bed sack will be taken by each indi - vidual as personal baggage in the barrack bag. Company Command - ers should check each enlisted man to see that he provides himself with extra underwear, socks, towels, tooth brush, paste, hand soap, etc., and that he has extra issue clothing; i. e., cotton blouse, breeches and O. D. shirt. 15. Instructions as to transportation, bills of lading, cooked meals, etc., will be furnished direct by the United States Property and Dis - bursing Officer. 16. Organisation commanders will see that the service record of

140 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL each enlisted man attending this camp of instruction is up to date and that same be brought to camp in possession of either the senior officer or non-commissioned officer of his organization. 17. All officers and enlisted men, with the exception of cooks and buglers, are directed to bring rifles with belts, bayonets and scabbards to camp with them. All officers and enlisted men will bring note books and pencils. In addition to the prescribed pistol and field glasses, bugl - ers will bring a flag kit (wigwag), Bugler's Manual, field message book and Manual of signalling or other book containing the signal code. All officers will bring message books, Field Service Regulations (1923 edition), pertinent Training Regulations (inc. 10-5, 145-5, 50-55, 150-5, 150-10, 200-5, 420-40, 420-85, 420-110, 420-115, 420-120, etc.), I. D. R., Waldron's Platoon Training, Grieve's Sketching and Map Reading, etc. All cooks will bring a copy of Manual for Army Cooks and any other pertinent available text books, such as the Mess Sergeant's Manual and the Mess Officer's Assistant. lit. The travel directed is necessary in the military service of the State. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General, Nebr. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENKRAI.'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN June 30, 1<!24. 1 General Orders, ( ) No. 6 \ 1. Pursuant to authority contained in letter MB-354.1 Neb-2, dated March 29, 1924, the 134th Regiment of Infantry, 110th Medical Regiment, 36th Division Train and State Staff Corps & Departments will go into Camp of Instruction on Government Rifle Range, Ashland, Nebraska, July 28 to August 11, 1924, inclusive, under command of Colonel Herbert J. Paul, Adjutant General's Department, State Staff Corps and Depart - ment.-, and upon completion of this tour of duty, the above named organ - izations will be* returned to their home stations.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 141 2. Attention is invited to Par. 932, N. G. R., 1922, and changes He. 3, N. G. R., March 22, 1923, and changes No. 4, N. G. R-. June 13. 1923. A strict compliance with these citations will be adhered to. 3. Details as to transportation, train schedules, supplies etc , will be handled by letter from this office. 4 The travel directed is necessary in the military service of the State. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN July 14, 1924. ( General Orders, ) \ No. 7 ) 1. Pursuant to authority contained in letter MB-354.1 Neb-2, dated March 29, 1924, a State Rifle Competition will be held at the Government Rifle Range, Ashland, Nebrsaka, August 12 to 21, 1924. inclusive. Dur - ing the rifle practice at the annual encampment, July 28 to August 11, 1924, inclusive, approximately seventy-five officerr -.rd men will be se - lected from those making the best records and will be held for competi - tive rifle practice in camp at Ashland, Nebraska, for a period of ten days immediately following tne annual encampment, and from these competi - tors will be selected the team which will represent the Nebraska National Guard at Camp Perry, Ohio, in September, 1924. 2. Upon completion of this tour of duty, the troops will be returned to their home stations. The travel directed is necessary m tne military service of the State. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL The Adjutant General, Nebraska OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General, Nebr.

Co. 3rd Bn., 134th Infantry, Lincoln, Nebraska. Pvt. Herman T. Brand, Wagon Co. No. 119, Lexington, Nebraska. Pvt. Dale Hess, Co. C, 134th Infantry, Beatrice. Nebraska. Pvt. Fred H. Weber, Service Co., 134th Infantry, York, Nebraska- Alternates Capt. Victor M. Hovis, Wagon Company No. 119, Lexington, Nebr. Pvt. lcl. Carl E. White, Co. G, 134th Infantry, Hastings, Nebraska. 2. With the exceptin of cots, full field equipment including both khaki and woolen uniform and overcoat will be carried by the enlisted men. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 258 Property & Disbursing Officer for Nebraska, is hereby detailed to at - tend the conference of U. S. Property and Disbursing Officers to be held at Washington, D. C, November 15-21, 1923, inclusive, under the pro - visions of Section 97, Act of June 4, 1920, as amended. Upon the ter - mination of the conference the Property and Disbursing Officer will re - turn to his proper station. 2. The expenses incurred in connection with this school are payable from the appropriation. "Arming, Equipping and Training the National Guard, 1924," Subappropriation, "Expenses, Camps of Instruction." Pay of grade with rental and subsistence allowances authorized. Transpor - tation requests including Pullman transportation, covering the travel to and from Washington, D. C, will be issued by the U. S. Property and Disbursing Officer of the State concerned. 3. The Militia Bureau will prepare the necessary pay rolls and make all payments. Each officer upon arrival should furnish the Militia Bureau with t'.ie necessary data concerning himself for the preparation of the pay roll, including date of departure from home station and cer - tificate re dependents. 4. Civilian clothes will be worn at business sessions, but it is de - sired that all officers have a >jniform for military occasions. 5. The travel directed is necessary in the military service. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 279 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN January 11, 1D24 Special Orders, No. 5 1. By direction of the Secretary of War, 1st Lt. Alexander Rieber, Company G., 134Lh Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, is hereby de - tailed to attend the Infantry School, Fort Benning, Ga., course beginning February 25, 1924. Upon completion of the course or when relieved by the Commandant, Lieutenant Rieber will return to his proper station. 2. Pay and .subsistence accounts will be settled by the Finance Officer at the School. Transportation requests excluding Pullman transportation will be issued by the United States Property and Disburs - ing Officer. Officers will be allowed five certs per mile over the short - est usually traveled route. Pullman expenses in addition to mileage are unauthorized. Expenses involved are chargeable against the procurements us follows: Transportation 13-MB-36-P-5044-A-420-4, Station No. 74 Pay 13-MB-36-P-2644-A-420-4, Station No. 74 Rental allowance 13-MB-36-P-2716-A-420-4, Station No. 74 Subsistence allowance 13-MB-36-P-2720-A-420-4, Station No. 74 4. Attention is especially invited to the fact that payment of the rental allowance is unauthorized if quarters of any kind are available for their occupancy at the school. 5. Inability to attend the School wiil be reported by wire to thi-s office at once. 6. The travel directed is necessary in the military service. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL H. C. Stein, Assistant Adjutant General, Nebraska.

STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN May 16, 1924 Special Orders, No. 52 tl. The Band Section, Service Company, 134th Infantry, Nebraska onal Guard, will report at the Adjutant General's Office, Lincoin, ■aska, not later than eleven o'clock, A. M., Friday, May 23, 1924, luty in connection with the celebration of Military Day. 2. The uniform to be worn will be the olive drab, including blouse, and caps and the web belts without side-arms or canteens. 3. Lunch will be served to all members of the band at the Lincoln University Club promptly at 11:30 A. M., and members of the band will inarch from the Adjutant General's Office to said club in a body, so as to arrive there promptly at 11:30 A. M. 4. Receipts will be taken for automobile transportation, same not to exceed the regular railroad fare from York to Lincoln and return, and the Commanding Officer of the Service Company will present same to tnis office, accompanied by proper voucher, for refund. The receipts should either be taken in the name of the Commanding Officer, Service Company, or the Warrant Officer on duty with the Band Section, in order to necessitate the making oi only one voucher for all transporta-

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 327 lion, and distribution can later be made by the individual in whose name the receipts are taken. 5. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN August 18, 1924. Special Orders No. 83 1. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captain Emory A. Drake

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 352 Medical Corps, 36th Division Train, Nebraska National Guard, is hereby detailed to attend the Medical Field Service School at Carlisle Barricks, Pennsylvania, for six weeks' course beginning September 1, 1924. Upon completion of the course or when relieved by the Commandant, Captain Drake will return to his proper station. 2. Pay and subsistence accounts will be settled by the Finance Officer at the School. Transportation requests excluding Pullman transportation will be issued by the United States Property and Dis - bursing Officer. Officers will be allowed five cents per mile over the shortest usually traveled route. Pullman expenses in addition to mile - age are unauthorized. 3. Expenses involved are chargeable against the procurements as follows: * Transportation 13-MB-36-P-6044-A-420-5, Station No. 74 Pay T3-MB-36-P-2644-A-420-5, Station No. 74 Rental allowance 13-MB-36-P-2716-A-420-5, Station No. 74 Subsistence allowance 13-MB-36-P-2720-A-420-5, Station No. 74 4. Attention is especially invited to the fact that payment of the rental allowance is unauthorized if quarters of any kind are available for their occupancy at the school. Inability to attend the school will be reported to this office at once. 6. The travel directed is necessary in the military service. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR. H J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL H. C. Stein, Assistant Adjutant General, Nebraska. The respective members of the above named team will report the Adjutant General's Office, Lincoln, Nebraska, not later than Ive o'clock noon, September 5, 1924. Transportation request from le station to Lincoln, Nebraska, enclosed herewith. 3. With the exception of haversacks and pack carriers, full field

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 357 equipment including khaki and woolen uniforms, overcoat and raincoat will be carried by the enlisted men; this to include mosquito bars. Both caps and campaign hats will be taken, the cap to be worn en route. No rifles, cartridge belts, cots or mess kits will be taken from home station, as these will be issued at Camp Perry. It is deemed advisable to take locker trunk instead of barrack bag if same is obtainable. Field glasses should be borrowed from company commander for this period of duty and telescopes, as large as possible to obtain, should be borrowed foi this tour of duty by each member of the team if possible. As this tour of duty will last approximately a full month, members of the team are cautioned to the necessity of taking with them sufficient underclothing, socks, shirts, etc. 4. Company commanders of companies from which enlisted men have been selected for the above named rifle team will furnish to each enlisted man a certificate in lieu of his service record; this certificate to give the man's grade and specialist's rating, if any, together with date of enlistment, period for which enlisted ,and date of qualification. These certificates are to be sent with the men in sealed envelopes and turned over by them to Major H. C. Stein, Team Captain. 5. The United States Property and Disbursing Officer for Nebraska will funrish transportation from home station to Lincoln, Nebraska, am from Lincoln, Nebraska ,to Camp Perry, Ohio; also commutation of sub - sistence at the rate of not to exceed $1.50 per day for the necessary travel period to 'Camp Perry, Ohio, for each authorized enlisted mem ber of the above named team. 6. The travel directed is necessary in the military service of the State. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. Stein Assistant Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT OFFICE OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL LINCOLN December 9, 1924. Special Orders, No. 108 1. By direction of the Secretary of War, Colonel Amos Thomas, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, is hereby detailed to attend tne G-4 Course, Army War College, Washington, D. C, course beginning January 2, 1925, and terminating February 7, 1925. Upon completion of the course or when relieved by the Commandant, Colonel Thomas will return to his proper station. 2. Pay and subsistence accounts will be settled by the Finance Officer at the Militia Bureau, Washington, D. C. Transportation re - quest 1 *, excluding Pullman transportation will be issued by the United States Property and Disbursing Officer. Officers will be allowed five cents per mile over the shortest usually traveled route. Pullman ex - penses in addition to mileage are unauthorized. 3. Expenses involved are chargeable against the procurements as follows:

373 Transportation— 13-MB-36-P-5044-A-420-5, Station No. 74. 4. Attention is especially invited to the fact that payment of the rental allowance is unauthorized if quarters of any kind are available for occupancy at the school. 6. Inability to attend the school will be reported by wire to tbia office at once. 6. The travel directed is necessary in the military service. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. Stein, Assistant Adjutant General, Nebraska.
